[C] : Contralateral corticospinal tract involvement
[D] : Right-sided analgesia
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient has a left C5 hemicord lesion, which means that the injury is on the left side of the cervical spine at the level of the 5th cervical vertebra. The spinal cord is organized such that the motor and sensory pathways are segregated into different regions. The corticospinal tract, which carries motor signals from the brain to the body, decussates (crosses over) at the level of the medulla oblongata, which is below the spinal cord. This means that a lesion above the decussation point will cause motor deficits on the opposite side of the body.

Given that the lesion is at the C5 level, it will affect the motor pathways that control the muscles of the right side of the body below the level of the lesion. This will result in spastic paralysis on the right side, as the motor neurons are damaged and cannot properly control muscle tone and reflexes.

Horner's syndrome (B) is characterized by ptosis (drooping eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on the affected side of the face. It is caused by disruption of the sympathetic nerves, which can occur with a lesion in the brachial plexus or sympathetic chain, but it is not typically associated with a hemicord lesion at the C5 level.

Contralateral corticospinal tract involvement (C) is not correct because the corticospinal tract has already decussated, so a lesion at the C5 level would affect the ipsilateral (same side) lower limb, not the contralateral (opposite side) limb.

Right-sided analgesia (D) would not be expected in this case because the lesion is affecting the motor pathways, not the sensory pathways. Analgesia refers to a loss of sensation, which would be more related to a lesion in the sensory tracts.

So, the answer is [A]. Spastic paralysis at the level of lesion.<|end|>

2025-12-11 20:48:54,515 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A previously healthy 19-year-old man comes to the physician with right-sided, dull, throbbing scrotal pain for 12 hours. He is sexually active with one female partner and does not use condoms. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a tender right testicle; lifting it provides relief. [B] : Testicular tumor

He has no prior bleeding history nor any relevant family history. The vital signs include: heart rate 190/min, respiratory rate 40/min, blood pressure 99/42 mm Hg, and temperature 36.6 °C (97.9 °F). His physical exam shows pale skin color, petechiae in the soft palate and in the upper and lower extremities as well as ecchymosis in the back of the hands and feet.
The complete blood count results are as follows:
Hemoglobin 8.9 g/dL
Hematocrit 41%
Leukocyte count 10,500/mm3
Neutrophils 53%
Bands 2%
Eosinophils 1%
Basophils 0%
Lymphocytes 33%
Monocytes 2%
Platelet count 450,000/mm3
The coagulation test results are as follows:
Partial thromboplastin time (activated) 30.0 sec
Prothrombin time 13.6 sec
International normalized ratio 0.99
Fibrinogen 364.9 mg/dL
The blood smear shows hypochromia, poikilocytosis, and large platelets, while a platelet aggregation test with ristocetin is normal. The overall bleeding time is increased. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

[A] : Von Willebrand disease
[B] : Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia
[C] : Bernard-Soulier disease
[D] : Scurvy
<|end|><|assistant|> The infant presents with spontaneous nosebleeds, multiple bruising, and petechiae without any trauma. These symptoms suggest a bleeding disorder. The complete blood count shows a low hemoglobin level, which indicates anemia, and a normal platelet count, which rules out thrombocytopenia as a cause of the bleeding.

The coagulation tests, including partial thromboplastin time (PTT), prothrombin time (PT), and international normalized ratio (INR), are within normal limits, which suggests that the coagulation pathway is functioning properly. The fibrinogen level is also normal.

The blood smear findings of hypochromia, poikilocytosis, and large platelets are not specific and do not point to a particular diagnosis. However, the normal platelet aggregation test with ristocetin and increased bleeding time suggest a defect in platelet function rather than a quantitative platelet disorder.

Let's consider the options:

[A]. Von Willebrand disease - This is a common inherited bleeding disorder that affects the blood's ability to clot. It is characterized by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor (vWF), which helps platelets to stick to the blood vessel wall and to each other. However, the normal platelet aggregation with ristocetin argues against this diagnosis, as ristocetin-induced platelet aggregation is typically abnormal in von Willebrand disease.

[B]. Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia - This is a rare genetic platelet disorder where the platelets lack the ability to properly aggregate due to a deficiency or dysfunction of the glycoprotein IIb/IIIa complex on the platelet surface. This would explain the normal platelet count, the normal coagulation tests, and the increased bleeding time. The normal platelet aggregation with ristocetin is also consistent with this diagnosis, as ristocetin primarily affects the binding of vWF to platelets, not the platelet aggregation process mediated by glycoprotein IIb/IIIa.

[C]. Bernard-Soulier disease - This is another rare inherited platelet disorder characterized by a deficiency of the glycoprotein Ib-IX-V complex, which is the receptor for vWF. This would lead to abnormal platelet adhesion and a prolonged bleeding time. However, the normal platelet aggregation with ristocetin is not typical for Bernard-Soulier disease, as this condition would usually show abnormal platelet function tests.

[D]. Scurvy - This is a disease resulting from a deficiency of vitamin C, which is necessary for the synthesis of collagen. Scurvy can lead to bleeding due to weakened blood vessel walls, but it is not typically associated with a defect in platelet function.

Given the information provided, the most likely cause of the patient's condition is Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia, which is characterized by a defect in platelet aggregation despite normal platelet counts and coagulation tests.

So, the answer is [B]. Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia.<|end|>

[A] : Elevated serum homocysteine
[B] : Thrombin inhibitor deficiency
[C] : Auto-antibodies directed against phospholipids
[D] : Resistance to clotting factor degradation

Which of the following will most likely occur?

[A] : The ribosome will recognize the mischarged tRNA and prevent its incorporation by removing the valine
[B] : The mischarged tRNA with valine will be incorporated in the codons that specificy for lysine
[C] : The mischarged tRNA will be degraded by the proteasome
[D] : The mischarged tRNA will be removed by the lysyl-tRNA synthetase
<|end|><|assistant|> The process of protein synthesis involves the ribosome translating mRNA into a polypeptide chain. During this process, tRNA molecules play a crucial role by bringing the appropriate amino acids to the ribosome in accordance with the codons specified by the mRN[A].

In the scenario described, a tRNA molecule that is supposed to carry lysine (Lys-tRNA) has been chemically modified to carry valine instead. This tRNA is then introduced into the cell, and an mRNA sequence that contains only codons for lysine is provided.

The ribosome will read the mRNA sequence and match the codons for lysine with the tRNA that has been introduced. Since the tRNA is mischarged with valine, it will still be able to pair with the lysine codons on the mRNA due to the anticodon-codon recognition process. The ribosome will incorporate the valine into the growing peptide chain at the positions where lysine should be, based on the mRNA sequence.

The other options are less likely because:
[A]. The ribosome does not have the ability to remove incorrectly charged tRNAs during translation.
[C]. The mischarged tRNA is not typically targeted for degradation by the proteasome during translation.
[D]. The lysyl-tRNA synthetase enzyme is responsible for charging tRNA with lysine, but it cannot correct a tRNA that has already been mischarged and introduced into the cell.

So, the answer is [B]. The mischarged tRNA with valine will be incorporated in the codons that specify lysine.<|end|>

[C] : Propranolol
[D] : Quetiapine
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's symptoms are suggestive of panic disorder, which is characterized by recurrent unexpected panic attacks. These attacks are sudden periods of intense fear that may include palpitations, sweating, shaking, shortness of breath, numbness, or a feeling that something terrible is going to happen. The patient also reports that these episodes seem to be triggered by stress, such as exams or school projects, and that he is increasingly anxious about having another attack in public, leading to avoidance behaviors.

For the long-term management of panic disorder, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are considered first-line treatment options. Citalopram is an SSRI and is commonly used for the treatment of panic disorder. It is generally well-tolerated and has a favorable side effect profile compared to other antidepressants.

Lithium is primarily used for the treatment of bipolar disorder and is not indicated for panic disorder. Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can be used to manage the somatic symptoms of anxiety, such as tremors and tachycardia, but it is not a primary treatment for panic disorder itself. Quetiapine is an atypical antipsychotic that may be used as an adjunctive treatment for panic disorder, but it is not typically used as a first-line agent.

Given the information provided and the typical treatment guidelines for panic disorder, citalopram would be the best medication for the long-term management of this patient's condition.

So, the answer is [A]. Citalopram.<|end|>

[C]. Random error refers to the variability in data due to chance, which could potentially explain differences in results, but the significant p-value in the first group suggests that the difference is not due to random error.

2025-12-11 20:56:39,814 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> During a Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection, Th1 cells secrete a factor capable of stimulating phagosome-lysosome fusion within macrophages. In addition, the secreted factors help activate macrophages to produce mediators such as NO, which are capable of destroying the invading pathogen. Furthermore, activation of the macrophages by the secreted factor eventually leads to the formation of a tubercle. Which of the following factors is secreted by Th1 cells and responsible for these actions?

[A] : IL-4
[B] : TNF-alpha
[C] : IFN-gamma
[D] : Histamine
<|end|><|assistant|> During a Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection, the immune response is crucial for controlling the spread of the bacteria. Th1 cells, a subset of T helper cells, play a significant role in this response. They are known for their ability to activate macrophages, which are cells that engulf and destroy pathogens.

The factor secreted by Th1 cells that stimulates phagosome-lysosome fusion within macrophages is IFN-gamma (Interferon-gamma). This cytokine is critical for the activation of macrophages, enhancing their ability to kill intracellular pathogens like Mycobacterium tuberculosis. IFN-gamma also promotes the formation of granulomas, which are organized structures of immune cells that help contain the infection. The granuloma eventually forms a tubercle, which is a hallmark of tuberculosis infection.

IL-4 is typically associated with Th2 responses and is involved in humoral immunity and allergic responses. TNF-alpha is also involved in the immune response and can contribute to granuloma formation, but it is not the primary factor secreted by Th1 cells for the activation of macrophages in this context. Histamine is mainly involved in allergic reactions and is not a cytokine secreted by Th1 cells.

So, the answer is [C]. IFN-gamma.<|end|>

The study ultimately found that folic acid supplementation was associated with lower rates of ASD in offspring (OR = 0.3, p < 0.01). Which of the following type of bias is most likely to have influenced these results?

[A] : Interviewer bias
[B] : Latency period
[C] : Recall bias
[D] : Survival bias
<|end|><|assistant|> The study in question is a retrospective survey, which means that the participants are being asked to recall past events or behaviors. In this case, the mothers are being asked to recall their prenatal consumption of folic acid. Recall bias is a type of bias that can occur in studies that rely on participants' memory of past events. It is a common issue in retrospective studies because participants may not remember past events accurately, or they may omit or exaggerate certain details.

Interviewer bias (A) would be a concern if the interviewer's behavior or questioning style influenced the participants' responses, but there is no indication in the question that this is the case.

Latency period (B) refers to the time between the exposure and the outcome. In this study, the latency period is the time from prenatal folic acid supplementation to the diagnosis of ASD in offspring. While it is an important consideration, it is not a type of bias but rather a factor that could influence the study's findings.

Survival bias (D) occurs when the study population is not representative of the general population due to a certain characteristic that also affects the outcome. In this case, there is no indication that survival bias is at play since the study is not about the survival of a particular group but rather the association between a prenatal intervention and a developmental outcome.

Given the information provided, recall bias is the most likely type of bias to have influenced the results of this study because it directly relates to the reliability of the participants' memory of their prenatal folic acid consumption.

So, the answer is [C]. Recall bias.<|end|>

[B] : Enoxaparin
[C] : Fondaparinux
[D] : Apixaban
<|end|><|assistant|> To determine which anticoagulant the subject is most likely consuming based on the elimination rate of 0.5 mg every 4 hours, we need to consider the pharmacokinetics of each listed anticoagulant.

[A]. Warfarin is a vitamin K antagonist and has a very long half-life, typically ranging from 36 to 42 hours. It is not eliminated quickly and would not be expected to have a rapid elimination rate of 0.5 mg every 4 hours.

Considering the elimination rate of 0.5 mg every 4 hours, enoxaparin (B) is the most likely anticoagulant that the subject is consuming, as it has a shorter half-life and would be eliminated more quickly than the other options listed.

2025-12-11 21:00:48,663 - INFO - question 204/1273 answer:B correct_answer:A False
2025-12-11 21:01:06,269 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 10-year-old Caucasian female with Turner's syndrome underwent an abdominal imaging study and was discovered that the poles of her kidneys were fused inferiorly. Normal ascension of kidney during embryological development would be prevented by which of the following anatomical structures?

[A] : Superior mesenteric artery
[B] : Inferior mesenteric artery
[C] : Celiac artery
[D] : Splenic artery
<|end|><|assistant|> During embryological development, the kidneys ascend from the pelvis to their final position in the posterior abdominal wall. This process is influenced by the rotation and growth of the kidneys in relation to the surrounding structures.

The kidneys initially develop in the pelvic area and ascend to their final position in the abdomen. As they ascend, they pass anterior to the spine and rotate so that their long axis is parallel to the spine. The ascending part of the kidney is the part that moves upwards during this process.

The inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) is an important structure that can influence the normal ascent of the kidneys. The IMA arises from the abdominal aorta and supplies blood to the large intestine. During normal development, the IMA can act as a physical barrier to the ascending part of the kidney. If the IMA is too anterior or too large, it can prevent the normal ascent of the kidney, leading to a condition known as a "renal ectopia" or "renal fusion anomaly."

In the case described, where the poles of the kidneys are fused inferiorly, it suggests that the normal ascent of the kidneys was impeded. The anatomical structure that would most likely prevent the normal ascent of the kidney during embryological development is the inferior mesenteric artery.

So, the answer is [B]. Inferior mesenteric artery.<|end|>

2025-12-11 21:01:42,157 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> Researchers are studying the inheritance pattern of mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) gene, the gene responsible for cystic fibrosis. It is believed that, in addition to the commonly found ΔF508 mutation, a novel mutation in this gene is found in a particular population under study. Which of the following would most likely suggest that these two loci have a high probability of being closely linked?

[A] : LOD Score < 1
[B] : LOD Score < 2
[C] : LOD Score > 3
[D] : LOD Score = 0
<|end|><|assistant|> The LOD (logarithm of the odds) score is a statistical measure used in genetic linkage analysis to evaluate the probability that two loci are close to each other on a chromosome and are therefore likely to be inherited together. A higher LOD score indicates a greater likelihood of linkage.

Here's what the LOD scores generally mean:
- A LOD score of 0 suggests no evidence of linkage.
- A LOD score between 0 and 1 suggests that linkage is not likely.
- A LOD score between 1 and 3 suggests that linkage is possible but not highly probable.
- A LOD score greater than 3 suggests that linkage is highly probable.

Given the options, a LOD score greater than 3 would most likely suggest that the ΔF508 mutation and the novel mutation in the CFTR gene have a high probability of being closely linked.

So, the answer is [C]. LOD Score > 3.<|end|>

[B] : Cryotherapy ablation
[C] : Loop electrosurgical excision (LEEP)
[D] : Hysterectomy
<|end|><|assistant|> Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) I, also known as low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL), is a mild form of precancerous lesion of the cervix. The management of CIN I depends on several factors, including the patient's age, desire for future fertility, and the presence of other risk factors.

For a young woman like the 28-year-old patient in the scenario, who is likely to desire future fertility and has a non-contributory medical history, the recommended management is often conservative. This typically includes:

- Close observation with repeat cytology (Pap smear) and HPV testing at intervals to monitor for progression of the lesion.
- If the lesion persists or progresses, then treatment may be considered.

The options for treatment include:

[A]. Close observation with Pap smear screening at 6 and 12 months, and HPV DNA testing at 12 months. This is a conservative approach that is often recommended for young women with CIN I, as many lesions will regress spontaneously, especially in the context of a young, otherwise healthy individual.

[B]. Cryotherapy ablation is a treatment option for CIN I, but it is less commonly used as a first-line treatment for young women due to the potential for damage to the cervix and the risk of complications during future pregnancies.

[C]. Loop electrosurgical excision (LEEP) is a treatment option for CIN I, but it is typically reserved for cases where the lesion does not regress with observation, or if there is a higher risk of progression.

[D]. Hysterectomy is a definitive treatment for CIN I but is generally reserved for women who have completed childbearing or when other treatments have failed or are not appropriate.

Given the patient's age and the fact that she is anxious but otherwise healthy, the most appropriate management would be close observation with follow-up Pap smears and HPV testing to monitor the lesion's status.

Darunavir has been particularly efficacious in recent patients; however, some have experienced an increased incidence of hyperglycemia. A new drug called DN501 is developed with the same mechanism of action as darunavir but fewer side effects. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of DN501?

[A] : Prevents viral transcription
[B] : Inhibits viral assembly
[C] : Inhibits viral entry
[D] : Prevents T-cell binding
<|end|><|assistant|> Darunavir is a protease inhibitor used in the treatment of HIV. Protease inhibitors work by inhibiting the protease enzyme, which is crucial for the maturation of the virus. This enzyme is responsible for cleaving the viral polyprotein into smaller, functional pieces that are necessary for the assembly of new virions. By inhibiting this enzyme, protease inhibitors prevent the virus from maturing and assembling new viral particles.

Given that DN501 is described as having the same mechanism of action as darunavir but with fewer side effects, it is reasonable to infer that DN501 is also a protease inhibitor. The options provided are related to different stages of the HIV life cycle:

[A]. Prevents viral transcription - This would be the mechanism of action for reverse transcriptase inhibitors, not protease inhibitors.
[B]. Inhibits viral assembly - This is the correct mechanism of action for protease inhibitors, as they prevent the maturation of the virus by inhibiting the protease enzyme.
[C]. Inhibits viral entry - This would be the mechanism of action for entry inhibitors, which block the virus from entering the host cell.
[D]. Prevents T-cell binding - This is not a recognized mechanism of action for antiretroviral drugs.

So, the answer is [B]. Inhibits viral assembly.<|end|>

Endometrial cells obtained from study participants are plated on growth media and the distribution of cell cycle phase is measured with flow cytometry. Drug X, which is known to activate cyclin-dependent kinase 4, is administered to all the cells, and the distribution of cell cycle phase is measured again 1 hour later. Which of the following is most likely to result from the action of drug X on the Rb gene?

[A] : G1 phase arrest
[B] : Prophase I arrest
[C] : Initiation of S phase
[D] : Completion of G2 phase
<|end|><|assistant|> The retinoblastoma (Rb) gene is a tumor suppressor gene that plays a crucial role in regulating the cell cycle. When the Rb protein is phosphorylated, it releases E2F transcription factors, which then initiate the transcription of genes required for DNA synthesis, thus promoting the cell's progression from the G1 phase to the S phase of the cell cycle.

Drug X activates cyclin-dependent kinase 4 (CDK4), which is a kinase that phosphorylates the Rb protein. When Rb is phosphorylated by CDK4, it becomes inactive and releases E2F transcription factors. This release of E2F allows the transcription of genes necessary for DNA replication, which is a hallmark of the S phase.

Therefore, the activation of CDK4 by drug X would lead to the phosphorylation and inactivation of Rb, which in turn would promote the initiation of the S phase in the endometrial cells.

So, the answer is [C]. Initiation of S phase.<|end|>

The authors were satisfied with their findings and, due to the prospective nature of their research, submitted their study to a journal as a cohort study (which they noted in the study title as well). However, the journal editor returned the article, suggesting that it should be submitted as a case series instead. The editor made this suggestion to the authors for which of the following reasons?

[A] : No prevalence assessment
[B] : Low number of patients
[C] : Ascertainment bias
[D] : Lack of risk calculation
<|end|><|assistant|> The study in question involved a small group of patients (14 patients), which is a relatively small sample size. In medical research, the number of patients in a study can be a critical factor in determining the type of study design that is most appropriate. A case series is a descriptive study that tracks patients with an outcome of interest (in this case, the use of cerclage wiring in femur fractures) without a comparison group. It is often used when there are too few patients to conduct a larger, more rigorous study design like a randomized controlled trial or a cohort study.

A cohort study, on the other hand, would involve following a group of patients over time who are exposed to a certain intervention (in this case, cerclage wiring) and comparing them to a group who are not exposed to the intervention. This type of study design allows for the assessment of the incidence of outcomes and can provide stronger evidence for causality than a case series.

Given the small number of patients in this study, the journal editor suggested that the study should be submitted as a case series instead of a cohort study. This is because a case series is more appropriate for small studies where it is not feasible to have a control group or to follow a large number of patients over time.

So, the answer is [B].<|end|>

2025-12-11 21:07:18,679 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 17-year-old female accidentally eats a granola bar manufactured on equipment that processes peanuts. She develops type I hypersensitivity-mediated histamine release, resulting in pruritic wheals on the skin. Which of the following layers of this patient's skin would demonstrate histologic changes on biopsy of her lesions?

[A] : Stratum corneum
[B] : Stratum granulosum
[C] : Stratum basale
[D] : Dermis
<|end|><|assistant|> Type I hypersensitivity reactions are immediate allergic reactions that occur when an individual who has been sensitized to a specific antigen (allergen) is re-exposed to that allergen. In this case, the allergen is peanut protein. The reaction is mediated by IgE antibodies that bind to mast cells and basophils. Upon re-exposure to the allergen, it cross-links the bound IgE on the surface of these cells, leading to degranulation and the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators.

The histamine released from mast cells and basophils increases the permeability of the blood vessels, leading to the classic symptoms of an allergic reaction, such as pruritic wheals (hives). These wheals are a result of fluid leakage from the capillaries into the dermis and the surrounding tissue.

Histologically, the changes in the skin during an allergic reaction like this would be most evident in the dermis, which is the layer of skin below the epidermis. The dermis is where mast cells and basophils are located, and where the histamine-induced vasodilation and increased vascular permeability occur. This would lead to the formation of the wheals and the associated erythema (redness) that is characteristic of an allergic reaction.

So, the answer is [D]. Dermis.<|end|>
2025-12-11 21:07:18,679 - INFO - question 219/1273 answer:D correct_answer:D True
2025-12-11 21:07:57,933 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with a persistent cough, fever, and vomiting. The past year the child has been admitted to the hospital 3 times with pneumonia. For the past 1 week, the child has been experiencing thick purulent cough and says that her chest feels ‘heavy’. Her stools have been loose and foul-smelling over the past week. Her parents are also concerned that she has not gained much weight due to her frequent hospital visits. She was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery and is up to date on all vaccines and is meeting all developmental milestones. On physical exam, the temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F). She appears lethargic and uncomfortable. Crackles are heard in the lower lung bases, with dullness to percussion. A small nasal polyp is also present on inspection. Which of the following is the most likely cause for the girl’s symptoms?

[A] : Dysfunction in a transmembrane regulator
[B] : Inefficient breakdown of leucine, isoleucine, and valine
[C] : Dysfunction in the motility of respiratory cilia
[D] : Deficiency in lymphocytic activity
<|end|><|assistant|> The clinical picture of a 4-year-old girl with recurrent pneumonia, a persistent cough, fever, vomiting, and a history of poor weight gain suggests a chronic underlying condition affecting her respiratory system. The presence of a small nasal polyp and the symptoms of a thick purulent cough and a sensation of chest heaviness are indicative of an issue with the clearance of respiratory secretions.

The most likely cause of these symptoms is a dysfunction in the motility of respiratory cilia. Cilia are tiny hair-like structures that line the respiratory tract and are responsible for moving mucus and trapped particles out of the lungs. When cilia do not function properly, mucus accumulates, leading to recurrent infections and symptoms like those described.

This condition is known as primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), which is a genetic disorder characterized by abnormal ciliary structure and function. PCD can lead to chronic respiratory tract infections, sinusitis, and bronchiectasis, which is consistent with the findings of crackles in the lower lung bases and dullness to percussion, suggesting the presence of fluid or mucus in the lungs.

The other options listed do not fit the clinical picture as well as a dysfunction in ciliary motility does:

[A]. Dysfunction in a transmembrane regulator is not typically associated with recurrent respiratory infections and the described symptoms.
[B]. Inefficient breakdown of leucine, isoleucine, and valine is related to maple syrup urine disease, which presents with different symptoms, such as poor feeding, vomiting, and a characteristic maple syrup odor in the urine.
[D]. Deficiency in lymphocytic activity is associated with immunodeficiency disorders, which can lead to recurrent infections, but the presence of nasal polyps and the specific respiratory symptoms point more towards a problem with mucus clearance rather than an immunodeficiency.

So, the answer is [C]. Dysfunction in the motility of respiratory cilia.<|end|>

2025-12-11 21:08:22,812 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 48-year-old man seeks evaluation at a clinic with a complaint of breathlessness for the past couple of weeks. He says that he finds it difficult to walk a few blocks and has to rest. He also complains of a cough for the past 3 months, which is dry and hacking in nature. The medical history is relevant for an idiopathic arrhythmia for which he takes amiodarone daily. He is a non-smoker and does not drink alcohol. He denies any use of illicit drugs. The vital signs are as follows: heart rate 98/min, respiratory rate 16/min, temperature 37.6°C (99.68°F), and blood pressure 132/70 mm Hg. The physical examination is significant for inspiratory crackles over the lung bases. An echocardiogram shows a normal ejection fraction. A chest radiograph is performed and shown below. Which of the following findings will most likely be noted on spirometry?

[A] : Decreased FEV1 and normal FVC
[B] : Decreased FEV1 and FVC with decreased FEV1/FVC ratio
[C] : Decreased FEV1 and FVC with normal FEV1/FVC ratio
[D] : Increased FEV1 and FVC
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with breathlessness on exertion and a dry, hacking cough for several months. The presence of inspiratory crackles over the lung bases and the use of amiodarone, which is known to cause pulmonary toxicity, suggest a possible diagnosis of interstitial lung disease (ILD) or pulmonary fibrosis.

In pulmonary fibrosis, the lung tissue becomes thickened and scarred, leading to a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests. This means that both the forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) and the forced vital capacity (FVC) are reduced because the lungs are less compliant and have a reduced total volume. However, the reduction in FVC is proportionally greater than the reduction in FEV1, leading to a normal or even increased FEV1/FVC ratio.

Given the clinical picture and the likely diagnosis of a restrictive lung disease such as pulmonary fibrosis, the spirometry would most likely show a decreased FEV1 and FVC with a normal FEV1/FVC ratio.

So, the answer is [C]. Decreased FEV1 and FVC with normal FEV1/FVC ratio.<|end|>

[A] : Administer zidovudine
[B] : HIV DNA testing
[C] : HIV RNA testing
[D] : Reassurance and follow-up
<|end|><|assistant|> The newborn in question is at risk for HIV infection because the mother has HIV and was on antiretroviral therapy during pregnancy. Although the viral load was relatively low (678 copies/mL), there is still a risk of transmission to the infant.

The standard of care for newborns born to HIV-positive mothers includes antiretroviral prophylaxis to reduce the risk of HIV transmission. Zidovudine (AZT) is the recommended prophylactic medication for newborns of HIV-positive mothers. It is typically started within 6-12 hours of birth and continued for 4 weeks.

HIV DNA testing (option B) and HIV RNA testing (option C) are used to diagnose HIV infection, but they are not the immediate next steps for prophylaxis in a newborn at risk for HIV. These tests would be used later to monitor the infant's HIV status.

Reassurance and follow-up (option D) would not be appropriate without taking steps to prevent HIV transmission.

2025-12-11 21:09:17,824 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 60-year-old woman presents to a physician for worsening shortness of breath and increasing abdominal distention over the last 3 months. She says that the shortness of breath is worse on exertion and improves with rest. While she could previously walk to the nearby store for her groceries, she now has to drive because she gets ''winded'' on the way. The patient was diagnosed with diabetes 5 years ago and is compliant with her medications. The medical history is otherwise unremarkable. The physical examination reveals gross ascites and visibly engorged periumbilical veins. Bilateral pitting edema is noted around the ankles. The finger-prick blood glucose level is 100 mg/dL. What is the mechanism of action of the anti-diabetic medication this patient is most likely taking?

[A] : Binding to the alpha subunit of the insulin receptor
[B] : Closure of ATP-sensitive K-channels in the pancreatic beta-cell
[C] : Increased gene expression of GLUT-4
[D] : Glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's symptoms of worsening shortness of breath, increasing abdominal distention, and bilateral pitting edema suggest the presence of congestive heart failure (CHF), which is a common complication in patients with long-standing diabetes. The fact that her symptoms are exertional and improve with rest further supports this diagnosis.

Given that the patient is compliant with her diabetes medication and her blood glucose level is normal, it is likely that she is on a medication that not only controls her blood glucose levels but also has beneficial effects on her cardiovascular system.

Let's review the options:

[A]. Binding to the alpha subunit of the insulin receptor - This is the mechanism of action of insulin itself, not typically used as a standalone anti-diabetic medication.

[B]. Closure of ATP-sensitive K-channels in the pancreatic beta-cell - This is the mechanism of action of sulfonylureas, which stimulate insulin release from the pancreatic beta-cells. While they can improve glycemic control, they do not have a direct effect on heart failure symptoms.

[C]. Increased gene expression of GLUT-4 - This is the mechanism of action of thiazolidinediones (TZDs), which increase insulin sensitivity in peripheral tissues. TZDs have been associated with fluid retention, which can exacerbate heart failure symptoms, making them a less likely choice for a patient with CHF.

[D]. Glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist - GLP-1 receptor agonists work by increasing insulin secretion, decreasing glucagon secretion, and slowing gastric emptying. They have been shown to have cardiovascular benefits and are less likely to cause fluid retention compared to TZDs.

Given the patient's symptoms and the need for a medication that does not exacerbate heart failure, a GLP-1 receptor agonist would be the most appropriate choice. These medications can help control blood glucose levels while also providing cardiovascular benefits, which is important for a patient with CHF.

So, the answer is [D]. Glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist.<|end|>

[A] : Hematogenous dissemination to the meninges
[B] : Retrograde migration up peripheral nerve axons
[C] : Reactivation of virus previously latent in dorsal root ganglia
[D] : Infection of oligodendrocytes and astrocytes

[A]. Hematogenous dissemination to the meninges - This is a common route for viruses to enter the CNS, but it typically leads to meningitis rather than the acute agitation and photophobia described.

[B]. Retrograde migration up peripheral nerve axons - This is a known route for certain viruses, such as rabies, to reach the CNS. However, rabies typically presents with hydrophobia and aerophobia, which are not mentioned in the case.

[C]. So, the answer is [B]. Retrograde migration up peripheral nerve axons.<|end|>

[A] : Tinea versicolor
[B] : Albinism
[C] : Vitiligo
[D] : Melanoma
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with hypopigmented skin, which means there is a loss of pigment in the skin. The key finding from the biopsy is the absence of melanocytes in the epidermis. Melanocytes are the cells responsible for producing melanin, the pigment that gives color to the skin, hair, and eyes.

[A]. Tinea versicolor is a fungal infection of the skin that can cause hypopigmented or hyperpigmented patches, but it does not involve the absence of melanocytes.

[B]. Albinism is a genetic condition characterized by a complete or partial lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes. It is caused by a defect in the production of melanin by melanocytes.

[C]. Vitiligo is an autoimmune condition where the body's immune system attacks and destroys melanocytes, leading to the development of white patches on the skin.

[D]. Melanoma is a type of skin cancer that arises from melanocytes. It is not characterized by an absence of melanocytes but rather by the presence of abnormal and proliferating melanocytes.

Given that the biopsy shows an absence of melanocytes, the most likely diagnosis is vitiligo, as it is the condition that specifically involves the loss of melanocytes in the skin.

So, the answer is [C]. Vitiligo.<|end|>

2025-12-11 21:11:47,804 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 62-year-old woman is evaluated because of a 3-day history of headache, nausea, and decreased urination. Laboratory studies show:

Na+ 136 mEq/L
K+ 3.2 mEq/L
Cl- 115 mEq/L
Mg2+ 1.4 mEq/L
Urine
pH 7.0
Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows a pH of 7.28 and a HCO3- concentration of 14 mEq/L. Prolonged treatment with which of the following drugs would best explain this patient's findings?"

[A] : Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
[B] : Eplerenone
[C] : Amphotericin B
[D] : Heparin
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with symptoms of headache, nausea, and decreased urination, along with laboratory findings that include hypokalemia (low potassium), hypomagnesemia (low magnesium), metabolic acidosis (low bicarbonate and low pH), and a urine pH that is not appropriately high for the acidotic state. These findings suggest a renal tubular acidosis (RTA), which is a group of disorders characterized by an inability of the kidneys to properly acidify the urine.

Among the options provided, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is known to cause a type of RTA called proximal renal tubular acidosis (Type II RTA). This drug can lead to the inhibition of carbonic anhydrase, which in turn can cause a decrease in bicarbonate reabsorption and an increase in urine pH, leading to acidosis. The hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia can also be associated with the use of this drug, as it can cause increased renal potassium and magnesium wasting.

Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would not typically cause the findings seen in this patient. Amphotericin B is an antifungal medication that can cause renal impairment but is not typically associated with RT[A]. Heparin is an anticoagulant and does not cause RT[A].

Given the clinical presentation and the laboratory findings, the prolonged treatment with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is the most likely cause of this patient's condition.

So, the answer is [A]. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.<|end|>

2025-12-11 21:13:10,569 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> An 11-year-old child complains of pain in the leg while playing. Blood pressure in the upper limb is 140/90 mm Hg and lower limbs are 110/70 mm Hg. There is a brachiofemoral delay in the pulse. Auscultation shows a loud S1, loud S2, and S4. There is a presence of an ejection systolic murmur in the interscapular area. Chest X-ray reveals the notching of the ribs. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

[A] : Pulmonic stenosis
[B] : Coarctation of the aorta
[C] : Aortic stenosis
[D] : Transposition of great vessels
<|end|><|assistant|> The clinical findings in this case point towards a diagnosis of coarctation of the aorta. Here's why:

1. The difference in blood pressure between the upper and lower limbs (140/90 mm Hg in the upper limb vs. 110/70 mm Hg in the lower limbs) suggests a narrowing of the aorta that is impeding blood flow to the lower part of the body, which is characteristic of coarctation of the aorta.

2. The brachiofemoral delay in the pulse is another classic sign of coarctation of the aorta. This occurs because the narrowing of the aorta causes a delay in the pulse wave reaching the lower extremities.

3. The auscultation findings of a loud S1, loud S2, and S4 are indicative of the increased workload on the heart due to the obstruction in the aorta. The loud S1 and S2 are due to the increased force required to open the stenotic aortic valve and the increased pressure in the left ventricle.

4. The presence of an ejection systolic murmur in the interscapular area is consistent with turbulent blood flow across a narrowed segment of the aorta.

5. The chest X-ray finding of rib notching is a classic sign of coarctation of the aorta. It occurs due to collateral circulation developing around the narrowed segment of the aorta, which leads to erosion of the inferior aspect of the ribs.

The other options do not fit as well with the clinical picture:

[A]. Pulmonic stenosis would not cause the blood pressure discrepancy between the upper and lower limbs or rib notching.

[C]. Aortic stenosis could cause a loud S1 and an ejection systolic murmur, but it would not explain the blood pressure discrepancy or rib notching.

[D]. Transposition of the great vessels is a congenital heart defect that would present with cyanosis and different clinical findings, not the signs described in the question.

So, the answer is [B]. Coarctation of the aorta.<|end|>

Analysis of the synovial fluid confirms septic arthritis, and the prosthesis is removed. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?

[A] : Staphylococcus epidermidis
[B] : Escherichia coli
[C] : Staphylococcus aureus
[D] : Pseudomonas aeruginosa
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient has a history of total knee arthroplasty and presents with signs of septic arthritis, which is an infection in the joint. In the context of a prosthetic joint, the most common causative organisms are staphylococci, particularly Staphylococcus aureus, and coagulase-negative staphylococci, such as Staphylococcus epidermidis.

Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of acute hematogenous infections and is known to cause septic arthritis, especially in the early postoperative period. However, in the setting of a prosthetic joint infection, coagulase-negative staphylococci, such as Staphylococcus epidermidis, are more common, particularly in late-onset infections. These organisms are part of the normal skin flora and can contaminate the surgical site during or after the procedure.

Escherichia coli and Pseudomonas aeruginosa are less common causes of prosthetic joint infections and are more often associated with infections in other contexts, such as urinary tract infections or infections in patients with compromised immune systems.

Given the patient's presentation with a late-onset prosthetic joint infection (4 months post-surgery), the most likely causal organism is Staphylococcus epidermidis, which is known for causing late-onset infections in prosthetic joints.

So, the answer is [A]. Staphylococcus epidermidis.<|end|>

The most likely explanation for the hypercalcemia in this patient with Hodgkin lymphoma is the production of PTH-related peptide (PTHrP) by the malignant cells. 2025-12-11 21:15:28,848 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 7-month-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician by his mother. She reports that the child develops severe sunburns every time the infant is exposed to sunlight. She has applied copious amounts of sunscreen to the infant but this has not helped the problem. On examination, there are multiple areas of reddened skin primarily in sun exposed areas. The child’s corneas appear irritated and erythematous. Which of the following processes is likely impaired in this patient?

[A] : Nucleotide excision repair
[B] : Non-homologous end joining
[C] : Homologous recombination
[D] : Mismatch repair
<|end|><|assistant|> The clinical presentation of the infant with severe sunburns and reddened skin in sun-exposed areas, along with irritated and erythematous corneas, suggests a condition known as xeroderma pigmentosum (XP). XP is a rare genetic disorder characterized by extreme sensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) rays from sunlight. This condition is caused by a defect in the nucleotide excision repair (NER) pathway, which is responsible for repairing DNA damage induced by UV light.

The NER pathway is crucial for correcting DNA damage such as thymine dimers, which are formed when DNA is exposed to UV light. In individuals with XP, mutations in the genes responsible for NER lead to an inability to repair this damage, resulting in a high risk of skin cancer and other complications.

The other options listed are different DNA repair mechanisms:

[B]. Non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) is a repair mechanism for double-strand breaks in DNA, which are not typically caused by UV light.
[C]. Homologous recombination (HR) is a repair mechanism for double-strand breaks in DNA, using a homologous sequence as a template for repair, and is also not primarily involved in repairing UV-induced damage.
[D]. Mismatch repair (MMR) corrects base pairing mismatches that occur during DNA replication, not UV-induced damage.

Given the symptoms and the nature of the DNA damage involved, the impaired process in this patient is nucleotide excision repair.

So, the answer is [A]. Nucleotide excision repair.<|end|>

MTC is associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2), but it can also occur sporadically. The presence of a family history of MTC in a first-degree relative increases the likelihood of a hereditary form of the disease.

Given the clinical presentation and family history, the most likely finding on biopsy of this patient's thyroid lesion would be stromal amyloid deposition.

2025-12-11 21:16:10,017 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A group of researchers decided to explore whether the estimates of incidence and prevalence rates of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) were influenced by the number of years it took to examine administrative data. These estimates were not only based on hospital discharges, but also on physician billing codes. For study purposes, the researchers labeled incident cases at the initial occurrence of SLE diagnosis in the hospital database, while prevalent cases were those that were coded as harboring SLE at any time, with patients maintaining their diagnosis until death. Which statement is true regarding the relationship between incidence and prevalence rates during the time period that might be chosen for this specific study?

[A] : Incidence rates will be higher during shorter time periods than longer periods.
[B] : The prevalence of SLE during consecutively shorter time windows will be overestimated.
[C] : The inclusion of attack rates would increase incidence estimates in longer time periods.
[D] : The inclusion of attack rates would decrease incidence estimates in shorter time periods.
<|end|><|assistant|> Incidence rate refers to the number of new cases of a disease that develop in a population at risk during a specific time period. Prevalence rate, on the other hand, refers to the total number of cases of a disease in a population at a given time.

[A]. Incidence rates will be higher during shorter time periods than longer periods. This statement is not necessarily true. Incidence rates depend on the number of new cases that occur, not just the time period. If more people are at risk during a longer period, the incidence rate might be lower because the same number of new cases would be spread over a longer time.

[B]. The prevalence of SLE during consecutively shorter time windows will be overestimated. This statement is true. If you look at a shorter time window, you might capture more new cases that have not yet been diagnosed or recorded, leading to an overestimation of the prevalence.

[C]. The inclusion of attack rates would increase incidence estimates in longer time periods. Attack rates refer to the proportion of a population that develops a disease during a specific time period after exposure. Including attack rates would not necessarily increase incidence estimates in longer time periods; it would depend on the exposure and susceptibility of the population.

[D]. The inclusion of attack rates would decrease incidence estimates in shorter time periods. This statement is not necessarily true. Including attack rates would provide more information about the new cases that develop, but it would not inherently decrease the incidence estimates.

So, the answer is [B].<|end|>

Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 111/50 mm Hg. She is responsive to painful stimuli. Lung examination shows bilateral rales. Abdominal examination shows a distended abdomen and intact abdominal surgical incisions. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis shows:
pH 7.44
pO2 54 mm Hg
pCO2 31 mm Hg
HCO3- 22 mm Hg
Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?"

[A] : Increase the FiO2
[B] : Increase the tidal volume
[C] : Increase PEEP
[D] : Increase the respiratory rate
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient is in the intensive care unit following emergent surgery for a small bowel perforation. She is on mechanical ventilation with a set FiO2 of 50%, tidal volume of 1000 mL, respiratory rate of 12/min, and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 2.5 cm H2O. Her arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows a pH of 7.44, pO2 of 54 mm Hg, pCO2 of 31 mm Hg, and HCO3- of 22 mm Hg.

The ABG results indicate that the patient is not adequately oxygenated, as evidenced by a pO2 of 54 mm Hg, which is below the normal range (typically 75 to 100 mm Hg). The pH is within the normal range (7.35-7.45), indicating that the patient is not in respiratory acidosis or alkalosis. The pCO2 is slightly low, which could be due to hyperventilation, and the HCO3- is within the normal range (22-26 mm Hg).

Given that the patient's pO2 is low, the primary goal is to improve oxygenation. The options provided are to increase the FiO2, increase the tidal volume, increase PEEP, or increase the respiratory rate.

Increasing the FiO2 would increase the fraction of oxygen the patient is breathing, which could improve oxygenation. However, increasing the FiO2 also increases the risk of oxygen toxicity and should be done cautiously.

Increasing the tidal volume could potentially improve oxygenation, but it also carries the risk of lung injury due to overdistension, especially in a postoperative patient.

Increasing PEEP can help to improve oxygenation by preventing alveolar collapse and keeping the alveoli open, which can increase the surface area available for gas exchange. However, increasing PEEP can also increase the risk of barotrauma and hemodynamic instability.

Increasing the respiratory rate would increase the minute ventilation, which could help blow off more carbon dioxide and potentially improve oxygenation by allowing more time for gas exchange. However, this could also lead to respiratory alkalosis if not carefully monitored.

Given that the patient's pH is normal and the pCO2 is slightly low, it suggests that the patient is not retaining carbon dioxide, which is a good sign. The best next step to improve oxygenation without significantly increasing the risk of lung injury or hemodynamic instability would be to increase the respiratory rate. This would allow for more frequent breaths, potentially improving oxygenation without the risks associated with increasing FiO2 or PEEP.

So, the answer is [D]. Increase the respiratory rate.<|end|>

[B] : Repeat blood cultures 24 hours after initial cultures were drawn
[C] : Repeat blood cultures 48 hours after initial cultures were drawn
[D] : Do not repeat blood cultures

This will help to confirm the persistence of the bacteremia and the effectiveness of the antibiotic therapy.

So, the answer is [B]. Repeat blood cultures 24 hours after initial cultures were drawn.<|end|>

[C] : Erythromycin
[D] : Azithromycin and ethambutol

2025-12-11 21:21:03,600 - INFO - question 249/1273 answer:C correct_answer:B False
2025-12-11 21:21:25,111 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A research group has developed a low-cost diagnostic retinal imaging device for cytomegalovirus retinitis in a population of HIV-infected patients. In a pilot study of 50 patients, the imaging test detected the presence of CMV retinitis in 50% of the patients. An ophthalmologist slit lamp examination, which was performed for each patient to serve as the gold standard for diagnosis, confirmed a diagnosis of CMV retinitis in 20 patients that were found to be positive through imaging, as well as 1 patient who tested negative with the device. If the prevalence of CMV retinitis in the population decreases due to increased access to antiretroviral therapy, how will positive predictive value and negative predictive value of the diagnostic test be affected?

[A] : PPV decreases, NPV decreases
[B] : PPV decreases, NPV increases
[C] : PPV increases, NPV decreases
[D] : PPV unchanged, NPV unchanged
<|end|><|assistant|> First, let's define the terms:

- Positive Predictive Value (PPV) is the probability that subjects with a positive screening test truly have the disease.
- Negative Predictive Value (NPV) is the probability that subjects with a negative screening test truly don't have the disease.

Now, let's look at the current situation:

- The imaging test detected CMV retinitis in 25 out of 50 patients (since 50% of 50 is 25).
- The slit lamp examination confirmed the presence of CMV retinitis in 26 out of 50 patients (25 detected by imaging plus 1 that was missed by imaging).

Now, let's consider the effect of a decreased prevalence of CMV retinitis due to increased access to antiretroviral therapy:

- With a lower prevalence of the disease, the number of true positives (people who have the disease and test positive) will decrease.
- The number of false positives (people who don't have the disease but test positive) will increase relative to the true positives because the total number of positive tests will be lower.

This means that the PPV will decrease because there will be a higher proportion of false positives among the positive results.

- The NPV is the proportion of true negatives among the negative results. If the prevalence of the disease decreases, the number of true negatives will increase relative to the false negatives, because there will be fewer people with the disease to miss.

Therefore, the NPV will increase because there will be a higher proportion of true negatives among the negative results.

So, the answer is [B]. PPV decreases, NPV increases.<|end|>

2025-12-11 21:23:09,918 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 40-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of a painless right-sided scrotal swelling. The patient reports that he first noticed the swelling several weeks ago, but it is not always present. He has hypertension treated with enalapril. His father was diagnosed with a seminoma at the age of 25 years. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a 10-cm, soft, cystic, nontender right scrotal mass that transilluminates. The mass does not increase in size on coughing and it is possible to palpate normal tissue above the mass. There are no bowel sounds in the mass, and it does not reduce when the patient is in a supine position. Examination of the testis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the mass?

[A] : Patent processus vaginalis
[B] : Dilation of the pampiniform plexus
[C] : Twisting of the spermatic cord
[D] : Imbalance of fluid secretion and resorption by the tunica vaginalis
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with a painless, right-sided scrotal swelling that is soft, cystic, and transilluminates. The fact that the mass transilluminates suggests that it is fluid-filled, which is characteristic of a hydrocele or a spermatocele. The absence of bowel sounds within the mass and the lack of change in size with coughing or the patient's position help to differentiate between these two conditions.

A hydrocele is a collection of fluid within the tunica vaginalis, which is the pouch of serous membrane that covers the testes. It can be caused by an imbalance of fluid secretion and resorption by the tunica vaginalis, leading to the accumulation of fluid. This is consistent with the description of the mass as cystic and transilluminating.

A spermatocele, on the other hand, is a cystic accumulation of sperm that occurs near the epididymis and typically does not transilluminate because it is not filled with clear fluid like a hydrocele.

A patent processus vaginalis (option A) is a condition that can lead to a hydrocele, but it is not the direct cause of the fluid accumulation.

Dilation of the pampiniform plexus (option B) is associated with varicocele, which typically presents as a "bag of worms" feeling upon palpation of the scrotum and does not transilluminate.

Twisting of the spermatic cord (option C), or testicular torsion, is an acute and painful condition that would not present as a chronic, painless, transilluminating mass.

Given the information provided, the most likely cause of the mass is an imbalance of fluid secretion and resorption by the tunica vaginalis, leading to the accumulation of fluid and the formation of a hydrocele.

So, the answer is [D]. Imbalance of fluid secretion and resorption by the tunica vaginalis.<|end|>

[B] : Hyperchromic red blood cells
[C] : Microcytic red blood cells
[D] : Bite cells
<|end|><|assistant|> Thalassemia is a genetic disorder that affects the production of hemoglobin, which is the protein in red blood cells (RBCs) that carries oxygen. The severity of the condition can vary depending on the specific mutation and how it affects hemoglobin production.

In the case of the Beta-globin gene mutation that leads to thalassemia intermedia, the mutation decreases the translation of the Beta-globin mRNA. This results in less Beta-globin protein being produced. Beta-globin is one of the two types of globin chains that make up hemoglobin. When there is a deficiency in Beta-globin production, it leads to an imbalance in the alpha to beta globin chain ratio, causing ineffective erythropoiesis and anemia.

The type of anemia associated with thalassemia is typically microcytic, meaning that the red blood cells are smaller than normal. This is because the imbalance in globin chain production leads to less hemoglobin being formed, which in turn leads to less cell volume and smaller red blood cells.

The other options provided do not typically describe the phenotype of thalassemia intermedia:

[A]. Macrocytic red blood cells are larger than normal and are typically associated with conditions like vitamin B12 or folate deficiency, not thalassemia.
[B]. Hyperchromic red blood cells have more hemoglobin per cell, which is not characteristic of thalassemia.
[D]. Bite cells are typically seen in conditions like G6PD deficiency, where there is damage to the red blood cell membrane that needs to be removed by splenic macrophages, not in thalassemia.

So, the answer is [C]. Microcytic red blood cells.<|end|>

2025-12-11 21:24:43,539 - INFO - question 257/1273 answer:C correct_answer:C True
2025-12-11 21:25:17,517 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A routine newborn screening test for phenylketonuria in a male neonate shows a serum phenylalanine concentration of 44 mg/dL (N < 20). He is started on a special diet and the hyperphenylalaninemia resolves. At a routine well-child examination 4 months later, the physician notices that he has persistent head lag. On examination, he has blue eyes, pale skin, blonde hair, and generalized hypotonia. His serum prolactin level is markedly elevated. Supplementation of which of the following substances is most likely to prevent further complications of this patient's condition?

[A] : Tyrosine
[B] : Pyridoxine
[C] : Thiamine
[D] : Tetrahydrobiopterin
<|end|><|assistant|> The newborn screening test result showing a serum phenylalanine concentration of 44 mg/dL, which is above the normal range, indicates phenylketonuria (PKU). PKU is a metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, which is responsible for converting phenylalanine to tyrosine. Without this enzyme, phenylalanine accumulates in the body, leading to various health problems, including intellectual disability, seizures, and other neurological issues.

The patient was started on a special diet to manage hyperphenylalaninemia, which is the high level of phenylalanine in the blood. This diet typically involves restricting phenylalanine intake to prevent further accumulation. However, the patient still presents with symptoms such as head lag, blue eyes, pale skin, blonde hair, generalized hypotonia, and a markedly elevated serum prolactin level. These symptoms suggest that the patient may have a form of PKU that is responsive to tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) supplementation.

BH4 is a cofactor for phenylalanine hydroxylase, and some individuals with PKU have a form of the enzyme that can be reactivated with BH4 supplementation. This can help lower phenylalanine levels and improve some of the associated symptoms.

Tyrosine (option A) is a product of phenylalanine metabolism and is not a cofactor for the enzyme. Pyridoxine (option B) and thiamine (option C) are vitamins that are not directly related to the treatment of PKU.

Therefore, the substance most likely to prevent further complications of this patient's condition, given the information provided, is tetrahydrobiopterin.

So, the answer is [D]. Tetrahydrobiopterin.<|end|>

A PPD skin test is done and reads 11 mm on day 3. Chest X-ray demonstrates a cavitary lesion in the right upper lobe. The standard anti-tuberculosis medication regimen is started. At a follow-up appointment 3 months later the patient presents with fatigue. She has also been experiencing occasional dizziness, weakness, and numbness in her feet. Physical exam is positive for conjunctival pallor. Lab work is significant for a hemoglobin level of 10 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume of 68 fl. What is the most likely cause of her current symptoms?

[A] : Inhibition of ferrochelatase
[B] : Increased homocysteine degradation
[C] : Increased GABA production
[D] : Decreased ALA synthesis
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's symptoms of fatigue, dizziness, weakness, and numbness in her feet, along with the physical finding of conjunctival pallor and the lab work showing a low hemoglobin level and low mean corpuscular volume (MCV), are suggestive of anemia. Given that the patient is on a standard anti-tuberculosis medication regimen, it is likely that she is being treated with drugs such as isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol.

One of the known side effects of isoniazid is peripheral neuropathy, which can cause symptoms like numbness and weakness. However, the question is asking about the cause of anemia, not neuropathy.

Isoniazid can also cause a deficiency in vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) because it acts as a competitive inhibitor for the enzyme pyridoxine kinase, which is necessary for the conversion of pyridoxine to its active form, pyridoxal-5'-phosphate (PLP). PLP is a cofactor for several enzymes, including those involved in amino acid metabolism and neurotransmitter synthesis.

One of the enzymes that requires PLP is the enzyme that converts homocysteine to cysteine, which is a step in the metabolism of homocysteine. If homocysteine degradation is inhibited due to a deficiency in PLP, homocysteine levels can increase, which is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular diseases and can also contribute to anemia.

The other options listed do not directly relate to the side effects of anti-tuberculosis medication or the symptoms described:

[A]. Inhibition of ferrochelatase is related to lead poisoning, not anti-tuberculosis medication.
[C]. Increased GABA production is not a known side effect of anti-tuberculosis medication.
[D]. Decreased ALA synthesis is not related to the side effects of anti-tuberculosis medication.

Given the information provided, the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms is the inhibition of homocysteine degradation due to a deficiency in vitamin B6 caused by the anti-tuberculosis medication isoniazid.

So, the answer is [B]. Increased homocysteine degradation.<|end|>

[D]. Vibrio cholerae causes cholera, which is characterized by profuse watery diarrhea, often described as "rice-water stools," and can lead to severe dehydration. 2025-12-11 21:27:31,480 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by staff of the group home where he resides because of worsening confusion for the past week. He has a history of major depressive disorder and had an ischemic stroke 4 months ago. Current medications are aspirin and sertraline. He is lethargic and disoriented. His pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 135/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows moist oral mucosa, normal skin turgor, and no peripheral edema. While in the waiting room, he has a generalized, tonic-clonic seizure. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium of 119 mEq/L and an elevated serum antidiuretic hormone concentration. Which of the following sets of additional laboratory findings is most likely in this patient?
 $$$ Serum osmolality %%% Urine sodium %%% Serum aldosterone $$$

[A] : ↓ ↓ ↓
[B] : ↑ ↓ normal
[C] : ↓ ↑ ↑
[D] : ↓ ↑ ↓
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with confusion, a history of ischemic stroke, and a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. The laboratory findings show hyponatremia (serum sodium of 119 mEq/L) and an elevated serum antidiuretic hormone (ADH) concentration. These findings suggest that the patient is likely suffering from the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH).

In SIADH, there is an excessive release of ADH, which leads to water retention, dilutional hyponatremia, and concentrated urine. The body tries to conserve water, which dilutes the serum sodium, leading to hyponatremia. The kidneys respond to this by excreting more sodium in the urine, which is why the urine sodium is typically high in SIADH.

The serum osmolality would be low because of the dilutional effect of retained water. Serum aldosterone may be normal or slightly decreased because aldosterone's primary role is to regulate sodium and potassium balance, and in SIADH, the problem is not the aldosterone level but rather the water balance.

Given these considerations, the most likely set of additional laboratory findings in this patient would be:

- Serum osmolality: Low (↓)
- Urine sodium: High (↑)
- Serum aldosterone: Normal or slightly decreased (↓)

So, the answer is [D]. ↓ ↑ ↓<|end|>

When she sees her neighbors walking their dogs outside, she is terrified and begins to feel short of breath. Recently, she has stopped picking up her children from the bus stop and no longer plays outside with her children in order to avoid seeing any dogs. Which of the following would be the best definitive treatment for this patient?

[A] : Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs)
[B] : Short-acting benzodiazepines
[C] : Systematic desensitization
[D] : Cognitive behavioral therapy
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient is experiencing a specific phobia, which is an intense, irrational fear of a specific object or situation that is out of proportion to the actual danger posed. In this case, the woman has an irrational fear of dogs.

[A]. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are a class of drugs typically used to treat depression and anxiety disorders. They can be helpful in the treatment of phobias, but they are not considered the definitive treatment.

[B]. Short-acting benzodiazepines can be used for the acute management of anxiety symptoms, but they are not a definitive treatment for phobias and are not recommended for long-term use due to the risk of dependence and withdrawal issues.

[C]. Systematic desensitization is a type of behavioral therapy that is considered the definitive treatment for specific phobias. It involves gradually exposing the patient to the feared object or situation in a controlled and systematic way, starting with the least anxiety-provoking situations and slowly working up to the more fear-provoking ones. This helps the patient to become desensitized to the fear stimulus.

[D]. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is a type of psychotherapy that is effective for a range of mental health disorders, including phobias. It involves changing the patient's thought patterns and behaviors that contribute to the phobia. While CBT is a good treatment option, systematic desensitization is a specific technique within CBT that is particularly effective for phobias.

Given that the question asks for the best definitive treatment, systematic desensitization (C) is the most appropriate choice as it is specifically designed to treat phobias through gradual exposure.

So, the answer is [C]. Systematic desensitization.<|end|>

[C] : Myocardial free wall rupture
[D] : Myocardial reinfarction

[D]. Myocardial reinfarction could be a possibility, but the acute respiratory distress and the findings on the chest x-ray point more towards a pulmonary cause.

2025-12-11 21:29:43,688 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 34-year-old male suffers from inherited hemophilia A. He and his wife have three unaffected daughters. What is the probability that the second daughter is a carrier of the disease?

[A] : 0%
[B] : 25%
[C] : 50%
[D] : 100%
<|end|><|assistant|> Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder, which means that the gene causing hemophilia is located on the X chromosome. Males have one X and one Y chromosome (XY), while females have two X chromosomes (XX).

Since the male in the question has hemophilia A, he has the hemophilia gene on his X chromosome. His wife does not have hemophilia, which means she has at least one normal X chromosome. However, since they have three unaffected daughters, it is likely that the wife is a carrier of the hemophilia gene (heterozygous for the trait), because if she were not a carrier, none of their daughters would be carriers either.

Each daughter has a 50% chance of inheriting the X chromosome with the hemophilia gene from her mother and a 50% chance of inheriting the normal X chromosome. The father can only pass on his Y chromosome to his sons (making them male) and his X chromosome to his daughters (making them female).

Therefore, the probability that the second daughter is a carrier of the disease is the same as for any of the daughters, which is 50%.

So, the answer is [C]. 50%.<|end|>

[A] : Tympanic membrane
[B] : Malleus
[C] : Incus
[D] : Cochlea

When the tuning fork is placed by the ear and then on the mastoid process, and air conduction is greater than bone conduction, this is known as the Rinne test. Normally, bone conduction should be better than air conduction, but in this case, air conduction is greater. This suggests that the patient has sensorineural hearing loss, as the issue is not with the conduction of sound through the outer and middle ear but rather with the inner ear or the auditory nerve.

The cochlea is part of the inner ear and is responsible for converting sound waves into nerve impulses that are then transmitted to the brain. Damage to the cochlea can result in sensorineural hearing loss, which is consistent with the patient's symptoms.

2025-12-11 21:31:17,435 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 31-year-old female patient complains of numbness and tingling in her left hand, weakness, difficulty with walking, dizziness, and bladder dysfunction. If a lumbar puncture is performed in this patient, which of the following would most likely be found in cerebrospinal fluid analysis?

[A] : Presence of 14-3-3 protein
[B] : Decreased glucose with neutrophilic predominance
[C] : Oligoclonal IgG bands on electrophoresis
[D] : Decreased IgG CSF concentration
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's symptoms and signs suggest a central nervous system disorder that affects multiple areas of the brain and spinal cord. The numbness and tingling in the hand, weakness, difficulty with walking, dizziness, bladder dysfunction, and the history of transient vision loss are all indicative of a demyelinating process. The presence of bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia, hyperreflexia, and bilateral clonus are neurological findings that can be associated with multiple sclerosis (MS), a chronic demyelinating disease of the central nervous system.

The MRI findings, although not provided in the question, would likely show lesions consistent with MS, such as white matter plaques.

In the context of MS, a lumbar puncture would typically reveal findings that are characteristic of the disease. One of the hallmark findings in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of patients with MS is the presence of oligoclonal bands, which are bands of immunoglobulins that are present in the CSF but not in the serum, indicating an immune response within the central nervous system.

Let's review the options:

[A]. Presence of 14-3-3 protein - This protein is associated with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, a prion disease, which is not consistent with the patient's presentation.

[B]. Decreased glucose with neutrophilic predominance - This finding is more typical of bacterial infections or other inflammatory conditions, not MS.

[C]. Oligoclonal IgG bands on electrophoresis - This is a common finding in the CSF of patients with MS and is indicative of an immune response within the central nervous system.

[D]. Decreased IgG CSF concentration - This would not be expected in MS, as the disease is characterized by an immune response that would typically increase IgG levels in the CSF.

Given the clinical presentation and the typical findings in MS, the most likely finding in the CSF analysis would be oligoclonal IgG bands on electrophoresis.

So, the answer is [C]. Oligoclonal IgG bands on electrophoresis.<|end|>

[A] : Keratoacanthoma
[B] : Basal cell carcinoma
[C] : Seborrheic keratosis
[D] : Kaposi's sarcoma
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's history of significant sun exposure and the description of the lesion as a 2 cm dome-shaped plaque with a central keratin plug are characteristic of a keratoacanthoma. Keratoacanthomas are rapidly growing, keratin-producing tumors that often present as dome-shaped nodules with a central keratin plug. They are considered to be a low-grade form of squamous cell carcinoma but are often self-limiting and can spontaneously regress.

Kaposi's sarcoma (D) is a vascular tumor associated with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) infection and is more common in immunocompromised patients, such as those with AIDS. It typically presents as red to purple plaques or nodules, not as a keratin-producing lesion.

2025-12-11 21:33:21,339 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 56-year-old man presents to his primary care doctor with intermittent chest pain. He reports a 2-month history of exertional chest pain that commonly arises after walking 5 or more blocks. He describes the pain as dull, burning, non-radiating substernal pain. His past medical history is notable for hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. He takes simvastatin and losartan. His temperature is 98.9°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 150/85 mmHg, pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 18/min. On exam, he is well-appearing and in no acute distress. S1 and S2 are normal. No murmurs are noted. An exercise stress test is performed to further evaluate the patient’s pain. Which of the following substances is released locally to increase coronary blood flow during exertion?

[A] : Adenosine
[B] : Inorganic phosphate
[C] : Prostaglandin E2
[D] : Transforming growth factor beta
<|end|><|assistant|> During exertion, the myocardium requires more oxygen due to the increased workload. The body has a mechanism to increase blood flow to the heart muscle (myocardium) when it is needed more, such as during exercise. This is achieved through the release of various substances that cause vasodilation, which is the widening of blood vessels, thereby increasing blood flow.

Adenosine is one of the key substances released during conditions of increased myocardial oxygen demand. It is produced from the breakdown of ATP (adenosine triphosphate) within the heart muscle cells. When the heart muscle is under stress, such as during exertion, the levels of adenosine increase. Adenosine then acts on the smooth muscle cells of the coronary arteries to cause vasodilation, which increases blood flow to the myocardium to meet the increased oxygen demand.

Inorganic phosphate is a byproduct of ATP breakdown, but it is not directly involved in the regulation of coronary blood flow.

Prostaglandin E2 is another vasodilator, but it is not the primary substance released during exertion to increase coronary blood flow.

Transforming growth factor beta (TGF-beta) is involved in cell growth and differentiation and is not directly related to the acute regulation of coronary blood flow during exertion.

So, the answer is [A]. Adenosine.<|end|>

Hematocrit: 35%

Platelet count: 20,000/mm^3
