However, his mother reports that he has stopped walking and appears weaker than he was a few months ago. He also has started having brief convulsive episodes over the past week. His parents are both healthy with no medical conditions. On exam, the child demonstrates muscle rigidity and diffuse muscle wasting. He is unable to stand or sit up straight. His patellar, Achilles, and brachioradialis reflexes are absent. Fundoscopic examination is unremarkable. A urine sample demonstrates metachromic granules. This patient’s condition is caused by a defect in which of the following enzymes?

[A] : Alpha-galactosidase A
[B] : Arylsulfatase A
[C] : Beta-galactocerebrosidase
[D] : Hexosaminidase A
<|end|><|assistant|> The clinical presentation of the child, including the history of delayed motor milestones, muscle weakness, and the presence of metachromic granules in the urine, is suggestive of a lysosomal storage disease. Metachromic granules are also known as "ceroid-laden macrophages" and are characteristic of Pompe disease.

Pompe disease, or glycogen storage disease type II, is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme acid alpha-glucosidase (GAA), which is responsible for the breakdown of glycogen within lysosomes. The accumulation of glycogen in tissues leads to the symptoms observed in this patient, such as muscle weakness, hypotonia, and the inability to stand or sit up. The absence of deep tendon reflexes and the presence of muscle rigidity and wasting further support this diagnosis.

The enzyme deficiencies associated with the other options listed are related to different lysosomal storage diseases:

[A]. Alpha-galactosidase A deficiency causes Fabry disease, which typically presents with angiokeratomas, hypohidrosis, and renal and cardiovascular complications.

[B]. Arylsulfatase A deficiency leads to metachromatic leukodystrophy, which is characterized by progressive demyelination and neurological decline.

[C]. Beta-galactocerebrosidase deficiency is the cause of Krabbe disease, which presents with irritability, muscle weakness, and developmental delay, but does not typically feature metachromic granules.

[D]. Hexosaminidase A deficiency results in Tay-Sachs disease, which is characterized by a cherry-red spot on the macula, progressive neurological deterioration, and the absence of reflexes.

Given the clinical presentation and the presence of metachromic granules, the enzyme defect in this patient is most consistent with Pompe disease, which is caused by a deficiency of acid alpha-glucosidase (GAA).

So, the answer is [B]. Arylsulfatase [A].<|end|>

2025-12-12 02:13:46,408 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 58-year-old male presents with an acutely elevated blood pressure of 220/140 mmHg. The patient complains of a headache and chest pain, and he has been vomiting for the last several hours. Physical exam demonstrates papilledema and a depressed level of consciousness. To treat this patient's hypertensive emergency, he is started on an IV medication commonly used in this situation. The agent exerts its effect by releasing nitric oxide as a metabolite, which subsequently activates guanylate cyclase and increases production of cGMP in vascular smooth muscle. Which of the following clinical effects would be expected from administration of this medication?

[A] : Decreased cardiac contractility
[B] : Increased left ventricular end-diastolic pressure
[C] : Decreased stroke volume
[D] : Decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
<|end|><|assistant|> The medication described in the question is likely nitroglycerin, which is a nitrate used to treat hypertensive emergencies. Nitroglycerin works by being metabolized to nitric oxide (NO), which then activates guanylate cyclase in vascular smooth muscle cells. This activation leads to an increase in cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP), which causes relaxation of the smooth muscle and vasodilation.

The vasodilation effect of nitroglycerin is most pronounced in the venous system, which leads to a decrease in preload (the volume of blood in the ventricles at the end of diastole). This reduction in preload results in a decrease in left ventricular end-diastolic pressure (LVEDP) and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP), as there is less blood returning to the heart.

The decrease in preload and the subsequent reduction in LVEDP and PCWP can lead to a decrease in cardiac contractility because the heart has less blood volume to pump with each beat. However, the primary effect of nitroglycerin in the context of hypertensive emergency is to reduce the workload on the heart by decreasing the preload, which can help to lower blood pressure and alleviate symptoms such as chest pain.

Given the options provided:

[A]. Decreased cardiac contractility - This is a possible effect due to the reduction in preload, but it is not the primary clinical effect sought in the treatment of hypertensive emergency.
[B]. Increased left ventricular end-diastolic pressure - This would be the opposite of the expected effect of nitroglycerin.
[C]. Decreased stroke volume - This could occur as a secondary effect due to decreased preload, but again, it is not the primary clinical effect.
[D]. Decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure - This is the expected clinical effect of nitroglycerin in the treatment of hypertensive emergency, as it reflects the reduction in preload and the subsequent decrease in the pressure transmitted back into the pulmonary circulation.

So, the answer is [D]. Decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure.<|end|>

[C] : Pituitary infarction
[D] : Pituitary hemorrhage

Hereditary spherocytosis is a genetic disorder that leads to the production of fragile red blood cells that are prone to hemolysis.

The most immediate and life-threatening complication of hereditary spherocytosis is splenic sequestration crisis. This occurs when the spleen becomes overwhelmed with the abnormal red blood cells and contracts to remove them, leading to a sudden and rapid drop in hemoglobin levels. This can cause severe anemia and may require an emergency splenectomy to prevent further complications.

So, the answer is [C]. Reintubate.<|end|>

2025-12-12 02:17:27,877 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> An 11-month-old male infant is brought to his pediatrician by his mother. She is concerned about his leg and his inability to stand. His mother explains that he can normally stand without help and can walk briefly on his own. However, he hit his right leg against a chair 2 days ago. The area became edematous and bruised overtime and the infant became unable to stand or crawl and cries when he puts weight on it. The mother denies any child abuse from her family or child care. The patient’s vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 80/40 mm Hg, heart rate 137/min, respiratory rate 25/min, and temperature 36.7°C (97.0°F). His length and weight are both between the 15th and 25th percentile. On physical examination, blue-grayish discoloration of the sclerae are noted. Respiratory, cardiovascular, and abdominal examinations are within normal limits for his age. There is joint hypermobility and decreased tone in both upper and lower extremities. The patient’s right calf appears slightly deformed, edematous, and warm to the tough. The patient begins to cry loudly when the physician palpates his leg. The patient’s X-ray shows an incomplete fracture of the right tibial diaphysis. What is the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms?

[A] : Insufficient production of procollagen type 1
[B] : Mutation in the gene encoding fibrillin-1
[C] : Defective collagen type 3
[D] : Dysfunctional structure of laminins
<|end|><|assistant|> The clinical presentation of the infant, including the inability to stand or crawl, joint hypermobility, decreased tone in both upper and lower extremities, and a history of a recent injury leading to an incomplete fracture, suggests a connective tissue disorder. The blue-grayish discoloration of the sclerae is also a common sign in certain connective tissue disorders.

[A]. Insufficient production of procollagen type 1 is associated with scurvy, which is caused by a deficiency of vitamin C. This condition does not typically present with joint hypermobility or a predisposition to fractures.

[B]. Mutation in the gene encoding fibrillin-1 is associated with Marfan syndrome, which can present with joint hypermobility and skeletal abnormalities. However, Marfan syndrome is not typically associated with a predisposition to fractures or blue-grayish sclerae.

[C]. Defective collagen type 3 is associated with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS), specifically the vascular type. This type of EDS can present with joint hypermobility, skin hyperextensibility, and tissue fragility, which can lead to easy bruising and a propensity for fractures. The blue-grayish sclerae can also be a feature of EDS.

[D]. Dysfunctional structure of laminins is associated with conditions like epidermolysis bullosa, which primarily affects the skin and mucous membranes, leading to blistering with minor trauma. It does not typically present with joint hypermobility or a predisposition to fractures.

Given the symptoms and the clinical findings, the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms is a defect in collagen type 3, which is consistent with a diagnosis of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

So, the answer is [C]. Defective collagen type 3.<|end|>

2025-12-12 02:18:07,831 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 21-year-old man comes to the emergency room with swelling and severe pain in his left lower leg that started 2 hours ago. He has no history of serious illness or trauma. His father has a history of pulmonary embolism. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily since he started college 3 years ago. He appears very distressed. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 92 kg (203 lb); BMI is 30.7 kg/m2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a tender and mildly swollen left lower leg; dorsiflexion of the left foot causes severe pain in the calf. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 184,000/mm3, a prothrombin time of 11 seconds, an activated partial thromboplastin time of 26 seconds, and positive fibrin split products. Ultrasonography of the left leg shows incompressibility of the popliteal vein with a hyperechoic mass and absent blood flow. The patient is administered a 5000 IU intravenous bolus of unfractionated heparin followed by a constant infusion. Six hours later, the activated partial thromboplastin time is 30 seconds. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

[A] : Antithrombin III deficiency
[B] : Factor V Leiden
[C] : Protein C deficiency
[D] : Antiphospholipid syndrome
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with acute onset of swelling and severe pain in the left lower leg, which is suggestive of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The physical examination finding of pain on dorsiflexion of the foot (Homan's sign) is a classic, though not highly sensitive or specific, sign of DVT. The ultrasonography confirms the diagnosis by showing incompressibility of the popliteal vein and a hyperechoic mass, which are indicative of a thrombus.

The patient's father has a history of pulmonary embolism, which could suggest a genetic predisposition to thrombotic events. The patient's smoking history and elevated BMI are additional risk factors for DVT.

The laboratory studies show a normal prothrombin time and activated partial thromboplastin time, but positive fibrin split products, which are indicative of thrombosis. The patient is started on unfractionated heparin, and the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) is used to monitor the effectiveness of the heparin therapy. The aPTT is prolonged, which is expected as heparin increases the activity of antithrombin III, thereby inhibiting thrombin and factor Xa.

The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms, given the family history and the acute presentation, is a hypercoagulable state. The options provided are all genetic conditions that can lead to a hypercoagulable state:

[A]. Antithrombin III deficiency is a condition where there is a deficiency of antithrombin III, a protein that inhibits thrombin and other clotting factors. This deficiency can lead to an increased risk of DVT.

[B]. Factor V Leiden is a genetic mutation that leads to a form of factor V that is resistant to inactivation by activated protein C, resulting in a hypercoagulable state.

[C]. Protein C deficiency is a condition where there is a deficiency of protein C, an anticoagulant protein that, when activated, inactivates factors Va and VIIIa. Deficiency in protein C can lead to an increased risk of DVT.

[D]. Antiphospholipid syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies, which can lead to a hypercoagulable state and an increased risk of both arterial and venous thrombosis.

Given the acute presentation and the family history of thrombotic events, Factor V Leiden (B) is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms. Factor V Leiden is the most common hereditary hypercoagulability disorder among individuals of European descent and is known to increase the risk of DVT, especially in young patients without other risk factors.

So, the answer is [B]. Factor V Leiden.<|end|>

2025-12-12 02:18:33,745 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> An 80-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of fatigue and lightheadedness. He does not have chest pain, palpitations, or difficulty breathing. He has a history of hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, osteoarthritis, and asthma. Current medications include simvastatin, metformin, lisinopril, albuterol, and ibuprofen. His pulse is 48/min and blood pressure is 89/50 mm Hg. He responds slowly to questions but is oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. His lungs are clear to auscultation and bowel sounds are positive with no pulsatile masses or bruits. Pedal pulses are nonpalpable, distal extremities are cold, and capillary refill time is 4 seconds. An ECG shows left axis deviation, a Q wave in lead III, a constant PR interval of 0.15 seconds with every third P wave that is nonconducted, and a QRS interval of .09 seconds. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

[A] : Dobutamine
[B] : Norepinephrine
[C] : Cardiac pacing
[D] : Epinephrine
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with symptoms of fatigue and lightheadedness, which are nonspecific but can be associated with cardiovascular issues, especially given his history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His vital signs show a low pulse rate (bradycardia) of 48/min and hypotension with a blood pressure of 89/50 mm Hg. The presence of dry mucous membranes suggests dehydration or poor perfusion.

The physical examination findings of nonpalpable pedal pulses, cold distal extremities, and prolonged capillary refill time indicate poor peripheral perfusion, which is consistent with his hypotension and bradycardia. The ECG findings of left axis deviation, a Q wave in lead III, a constant PR interval with every third P wave that is nonconducted (suggestive of a 2:1 atrioventricular block), and a normal QRS duration are indicative of a third-degree (complete) atrioventricular block.

In the setting of a third-degree AV block with hemodynamic instability (evidenced by hypotension and bradycardia), immediate cardiac pacing is required to maintain an adequate heart rate and blood pressure. Dobutamine and norepinephrine are inotropic agents that could be used to support blood pressure and heart rate, but they would not address the underlying conduction issue. Epinephrine is typically used in the setting of cardiac arrest or anaphylaxis and is not the first-line treatment for a third-degree AV block with hemodynamic compromise.

So, the answer is [C]. Cardiac pacing.<|end|>

The data obtained shows, of the 200 alcoholics who were followed-up, 30 developed GERD; and out of the 400 non-alcoholics, 30 developed GERD. What fraction of GERD can be prevented in the general population if alcohol is no longer consumed in this town?

[A] : 45/195
[B] : 30/400
[C] : (30/200) / (30/400)
[D] : 30/200
<|end|><|assistant|> First, we need to calculate the incidence of GERD in both the alcoholic and non-alcoholic groups.

For the alcoholic group:
- 30 out of 200 alcoholics developed GER[D].

For the non-alcoholic group:
- 30 out of 400 non-alcoholics developed GER[D].

Now, we want to find out the fraction of GERD that can be prevented if alcohol is no longer consumed. This is essentially the difference in the incidence rates between the alcoholic and non-alcoholic groups.

The incidence rate in the alcoholic group is 30/200, and in the non-alcoholic group, it is 30/400.

To find the preventable fraction, we subtract the incidence rate in the non-alcoholic group from the incidence rate in the alcoholic group:

Preventable fraction = (Incidence in alcoholics) - (Incidence in non-alcoholics)
Preventable fraction = (30/200) - (30/400)

Preventable fraction = (60/400) - (30/400)

Preventable fraction = (60 - 30) / 400
Preventable fraction = 30 / 400

2025-12-12 02:24:08,812 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 41-year-old man presents to the clinic with the complaints of abdominal discomfort and cramping for the past 4 months. He also mentions that he has grossly bloody stool and most of the time an urge to defecate. He has a history of bulimia with laxative abuse several years ago. He admits having lost about 5 lb in the past month. His temperature is 37° C (98.6° F), respiratory rate is 15/min, pulse is 77/min, and blood pressure is 105/86 mm Hg. On physical examination, a mild conjunctival pallor is evident, and the rectum is erythematous, indurated, and tender. Colonoscopy demonstrates continuous mucosal lesions throughout the rectum to the hepatic flexure of the colon. What is the most likely diagnosis?

[A] : Ulcerative colitis
[B] : Celiac disease
[C] : Irritable bowel syndrome
[D] : Crohn’s disease
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with symptoms of abdominal discomfort, cramping, bloody stool, and an urge to defecate. These symptoms, along with the history of weight loss and the findings of continuous mucosal lesions throughout the rectum to the hepatic flexure of the colon on colonoscopy, are suggestive of an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

Ulcerative colitis (UC) typically presents with continuous mucosal inflammation starting from the rectum and extending proximally in a continuous fashion, which matches the colonoscopy findings in this case. It is also associated with bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain.

Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder that affects the small intestine and is triggered by the ingestion of gluten. It does not typically present with continuous mucosal lesions in the colon and is not associated with bloody stools.

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a functional gastrointestinal disorder characterized by a group of symptoms including abdominal pain and changes in the pattern of bowel movements without any evidence of underlying damage. IBS does not cause mucosal lesions or bloody stools.

Crohn’s disease is another type of IBD that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract from the mouth to the anus. However, Crohn's disease typically presents with patchy areas of inflammation ("skip lesions") rather than continuous lesions.

Given the continuous nature of the mucosal lesions and the symptoms described, the most likely diagnosis is ulcerative colitis.

So, the answer is [A]. Ulcerative colitis.<|end|>
2025-12-12 02:24:08,813 - INFO - question 871/1273 answer:A correct_answer:A True
2025-12-12 02:24:40,218 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 45-year-old man presents to your office with a 2-year history of moderate-to-severe pelvic pain, irritative voiding urinary symptoms (frequency and dysuria), and occasional frank blood in his semen with painful ejaculation. He has been evaluated by several practitioners, who have all prescribed antimicrobial therapy, including ciprofloxacin, with no improvement and leading to emotional distress and sleep disturbances. The physical examination is unremarkable, except for a mildly tender prostate, without masses or nodules. There are no testicular masses, hernias, or hemorrhoids. Additionally to this health issue, you have also been following him for recurrent abdominal pain, periods of constipation and diarrhea, and fatigability, with all test results within the normal range thus far. A summary of recent tests is shown in the following table:
Urine test
Sample White cells Culture
Mid-stream urine Negative Negative
Expressed prostatic secretion Positive Negative
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

[A] : Benign prostatic hyperplasia
[B] : Chronic, non-bacterial prostatitis
[C] : Chronic prostatitis by resistant Escherichia coli
[D] : Interstitial cystitis
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with a history of moderate-to-severe pelvic pain, irritative voiding urinary symptoms, and occasional frank blood in his semen with painful ejaculation. These symptoms are suggestive of a chronic prostatitis syndrome. The fact that he has not responded to multiple courses of antimicrobial therapy, including ciprofloxacin, suggests that the condition is not due to a simple bacterial infection.

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) typically presents with urinary symptoms such as difficulty starting urination, weak stream, and nocturia, but it is less likely to cause pelvic pain, dyspareunia (painful ejaculation), or hematospermia (blood in semen).

Chronic, non-bacterial prostatitis, also known as chronic pelvic pain syndrome, is a diagnosis of exclusion when bacterial infection has been ruled out. It is characterized by pelvic or perineal pain, which may be associated with urinary symptoms, and is not caused by a bacterial infection. The patient's symptoms fit this description, and the lack of response to antibiotics supports this diagnosis.

Chronic prostatitis by resistant Escherichia coli would likely show positive results in the expressed prostatic secretion culture, indicating the presence of bacteria. Since the culture is negative, this makes resistant E. coli an unlikely cause.

Interstitial cystitis is a chronic condition characterized by bladder pain and frequent, painful urination, but it does not typically cause painful ejaculation or blood in the semen.

Given the information provided, the most likely diagnosis for this patient is chronic, non-bacterial prostatitis.

So, the answer is [B]. Chronic, non-bacterial prostatitis.<|end|>
2025-12-12 02:24:40,219 - INFO - question 872/1273 answer:B correct_answer:B True
2025-12-12 02:25:01,085 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> An 18-year-old male presents to the emergency department trauma bay with a gunshot wound to the abdomen. The patient undergoes an exploratory laparotomy, during which, it is discovered that his splenic artery was damaged at its origin from the celiac trunk. The surgeon ligates the splenic artery at its origin. Which of the following arteries will now be hypoperfused as a result?

[A] : Left gastric artery
[B] : Gastroduodenal artery
[C] : Left gastroepiploic artery
[D] : Common hepatic artery
<|end|><|assistant|> The splenic artery is a branch of the celiac trunk that supplies blood to the spleen, pancreas, and parts of the stomach and colon. When the splenic artery is ligated at its origin, the areas that would normally receive blood from it will be affected.

[A]. The left gastric artery is a branch of the celiac trunk that supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach. It is not directly affected by the ligation of the splenic artery.

[B]. The gastroduodenal artery is a branch of the common hepatic artery, which itself is a branch of the celiac trunk. The gastroduodenal artery supplies the stomach and the duodenum. It is not directly affected by the ligation of the splenic artery.

[C]. The left gastroepiploic artery is a branch of the splenic artery that supplies the greater curvature of the stomach. If the splenic artery is ligated at its origin, the left gastroepiploic artery will be hypoperfused because it no longer has a source of blood flow.

[D]. The common hepatic artery is a branch of the celiac trunk that gives rise to the gastroduodenal artery and the proper hepatic artery. It is not directly affected by the ligation of the splenic artery.

So, the answer is [C]. Left gastroepiploic artery.<|end|>

[D] : Sumatriptan

Which of the following is the correct method of transporting the amputated finger?

[A] : Submerge the finger in ice water
[B] : Wrap the finger in moist gauze
[C] : Wrap finger in moist gauze, put in a plastic bag, and place on ice
[D] : Wrap the finger in moist gauze and submerge in ice water
<|end|><|assistant|> When transporting an amputated part, such as a finger, it is important to preserve the tissue for potential reattachment surgery. The tissue should be kept cool but not frozen, as freezing can damage the cells and reduce the chances of successful reattachment.

Option A, submerging the finger in ice water, is not recommended because direct contact with ice can cause frostbite and damage the tissue.

Option B, wrapping the finger in moist gauze, is a good first step to keep the tissue moist and protected. However, this option does not mention the use of a waterproof bag or the placement on ice, which are important to prevent contamination and to keep the tissue cool.

Option C, wrapping the finger in moist gauze, placing it in a plastic bag, and then placing the bag on ice, is the correct method. This approach keeps the finger moist, prevents contamination, and maintains the tissue at a cool temperature without freezing it.

Option D, wrapping the finger in moist gauze and submerging it in ice water, is not recommended for the same reasons as option A; direct contact with ice can damage the tissue.

So, the answer is [C].<|end|>

[C]. Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder affecting females, characterized by the absence of all or part of a second sex chromosome. It can lead to various physical abnormalities and health issues, but it is not commonly associated with hypertension or the symptoms described.

[D]. Takayasu's arteritis is a rare form of vasculitis that affects large arteries, such as the aorta and its main branches. It typically occurs in young women and can cause high blood pressure, but it is less likely to present with the symptoms of facial flushing and temperature dysregulation.

[B] : Caspase 1
[C] : Protein phosphatase
[D] : Tyrosine kinase
<|end|><|assistant|> The process described involves the detection of cellular stress by the NLRP3 inflammasome, which is a part of the innate immune system. Upon detection of stress signals, NLRP3 interacts with the apoptosis-associated speck-like protein containing CARD (ASC). This interaction leads to the formation of a protein speck that consists of multimers of ASC dimers.

Caspase-1 is an enzyme that plays a crucial role in the inflammatory response by cleaving pro-inflammatory cytokines such as pro-IL-1β and pro-IL-18 into their active forms. 2025-12-12 02:29:40,207 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> The ribosome is an essential organelle that plays an important role in the synthesis of new proteins. The location of the ribosome within the cell can vary and provides a clue to the function of the particular cell. What ribosome location is essential for protein-secreting cells?

[A] : Rough endoplasmic reticulum
[B] : Smooth endoplasmic reticulum
[C] : Cytosol
[D] : Nucleus
<|end|><|assistant|> Ribosomes are the cellular structures responsible for protein synthesis. They can be found in various locations within a cell, each location serving a specific function.

[A]. Rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER) - Ribosomes attached to the RER are involved in the synthesis of proteins that are destined to be secreted from the cell, inserted into the cell's plasma membrane, or shipped to an organelle within the endomembrane system. The RER is studded with ribosomes, giving it a "rough" appearance under a microscope.

[B]. Smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER) - The SER lacks ribosomes on its surface and is involved in lipid synthesis and metabolism, detoxification processes, and calcium storage, but not in protein synthesis.

[C]. Cytosol - Some ribosomes float freely in the cytosol and are responsible for synthesizing proteins that function within the cytosol itself.

[D]. Nucleus - Ribosomes are not typically found in the nucleus. The nucleus is the site of transcription, where DNA is transcribed into RN[A].

For protein-secreting cells, the ribosomes are essential for synthesizing proteins that will be secreted. These proteins are synthesized on ribosomes bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum, where they enter the secretory pathway.

So, the answer is [A]. Rough endoplasmic reticulum.<|end|>

[D]. No further testing is necessary - This is not correct because the patient is sexually active and should be screened for sexually transmitted infections.

Given the information provided and the current guidelines, the best recommendation for this patient at this time is to screen for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis.

So, the answer is [A]. Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis screening.<|end|>

Which of the following is most likely to be found in this patient's history?

2025-12-12 02:30:52,168 - INFO - question 888/1273 answer:C correct_answer:A False
2025-12-12 02:31:27,708 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> An academic obstetrician is conducting a retrospective cohort study that evaluates the risk of placenta accreta at all statewide medical centers. Per chart review he finds that a prior cesarian birth is associated with a statistically significant increased risk of placenta accreta. The relative risk associated with this finding is 1.23. The associated p-value is 0.03. Which of the following statements is the best interpretation of the reported association in the context of the study?

[A] : The 99% confidence interval includes the null hypothesis.
[B] : The chance of bias in favor of the alternative hypothesis is 3%.
[C] : The p-value represents the likelihood of seeing an increased risk of placenta accreta in women with prior cesarian birth, assuming the alternative hypothesis is true.
[D] : The p-value represents the likelihood that the alternative hypothesis is false.
<|end|><|assistant|> First, let's understand what the p-value represents in the context of a statistical test. The p-value is the probability of observing a result as extreme as the one in your sample data, or something more extreme, if the null hypothesis were true. In other words, it's a measure of the evidence against the null hypothesis.

Now, let's go through the options:

[A]. The 99% confidence interval includes the null hypothesis.
- This statement is incorrect because a p-value of 0.03 indicates that the confidence interval does not include the null value (usually 1 for a relative risk), which suggests that the result is statistically significant at the 0.05 level, and likely at the 0.01 level as well.

[B]. The chance of bias in favor of the alternative hypothesis is 3%.
- This statement is incorrect because the p-value does not represent the chance of bias. It represents the probability of observing the data (or something more extreme) if the null hypothesis were true.

[C]. The p-value represents the likelihood of seeing an increased risk of placenta accreta in women with prior cesarian birth, assuming the alternative hypothesis is true.
- This statement is incorrect because the p-value does not represent the likelihood of the alternative hypothesis being true. It represents the probability of the observed data (or more extreme) under the assumption that the null hypothesis is true.

[D]. The p-value represents the likelihood that the alternative hypothesis is false.
- This statement is incorrect because the p-value does not represent the likelihood that the alternative hypothesis is false. It is a measure of the evidence against the null hypothesis, not the alternative hypothesis.

The correct interpretation of the p-value is that it represents the probability of observing the data (or something more extreme) if the null hypothesis were true. In this case, the null hypothesis would be that there is no increased risk of placenta accreta with a prior cesarian birth. A p-value of 0.03 suggests that there is a 3% chance of observing the data we have (or something more extreme) if there really was no increased risk associated with a prior cesarian birth. Since the p-value is less than 0.05, we typically consider the result to be statistically significant, and we would reject the null hypothesis in favor of the alternative hypothesis, which suggests that there is an increased risk of placenta accreta with a prior cesarian birth.

So, the answer is [C].<|end|>

[B] : Factor XI
[C] : Vitamin K
[D] : Antithrombin III
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's symptoms and lab results suggest a bleeding disorder. The normal platelet count rules out thrombocytopenia. [C] : Estrogen
[D] : Tamoxifen
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient has a T-score of -3.2 standard deviations, which indicates osteoporosis. Pharmacological treatment options for osteoporosis include bisphosphonates (such as alendronate), selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) like tamoxifen, calcitonin, and hormone replacement therapy (HRT) with estrogen. Calcitonin is another option for the treatment of osteoporosis, but it is generally considered less effective than bisphosphonates and is often used for patients who cannot tolerate other treatments.

Given the information provided and the standard treatment guidelines for osteoporosis, the most appropriate next step in pharmacotherapy for this patient would be to start a bisphosphonate, such as alendronate.

Physical examination reveals 2+ bilateral pitting edema. Chest auscultation reveals bibasilar crackles. Which of the following is associated with this patient’s condition?

[A] : Decreased glomerular filtration rate (GFR)
[B] : Decreased extracellular fluid (ECF) volume
[C] : Increased renal blood flow
[D] : Increased renal tubular sodium reabsorption
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with exertional dyspnea, dry cough, orthopnea (needing extra pillows to sleep), paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (waking up at night to catch his breath), and bilateral pitting edema. These symptoms are suggestive of heart failure. The presence of bibasilar crackles on chest auscultation further supports this diagnosis.

Chronic alcohol consumption can lead to cardiomyopathy, which is a common cause of heart failure. Alcohol has a diuretic effect, which can lead to dehydration and decreased extracellular fluid (ECF) volume. However, in the setting of heart failure, the body compensates by retaining fluid to increase the preload and maintain cardiac output, despite the initial diuretic effect of alcohol.

Given the patient's symptoms and history, the most likely scenario is that his chronic alcohol use has led to the development of heart failure. In heart failure, the kidneys perceive a reduced effective blood volume due to poor perfusion, despite the actual volume status. This triggers a series of neurohormonal responses, including the activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), which leads to increased renal tubular sodium reabsorption and water retention in an attempt to improve cardiac output.

Therefore, the condition associated with this patient's presentation is increased renal tubular sodium reabsorption as a compensatory mechanism in response to perceived hypovolemia due to heart failure.

So, the answer is [D]. Increased renal tubular sodium reabsorption.<|end|>

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe protein-energy malnutrition characterized by edema, an enlarged liver with fatty infiltrates, and other signs of protein deficiency. It typically occurs in children who have had adequate caloric intake but insufficient protein intake. The edema, particularly in the ankles and feet, and the irritability and drowsiness are consistent with this diagnosis.

Marasmus is another form of severe malnutrition, but it is characterized by a deficiency in both calories and protein. Children with marasmus typically present with severe wasting and no edema.

Beriberi is caused by a deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1) and can lead to neurological and cardiovascular symptoms, but it does not typically present with edema or ascites.

Rickets is a disease caused by vitamin D deficiency, leading to softening and weakening of the bones in children. It is associated with bone pain, delayed growth, and skeletal deformities, but not with edema or ascites.

Given the symptoms of edema, ascites, hepatomegaly, and the history of inadequate nutrition, the most likely diagnosis is kwashiorkor.

[B] : Autosomal recessive
[C] : Noninherited somatic mutation

Given the information provided and the typical inheritance pattern of Fragile X syndrome, the most likely inheritance pattern of the disorder in this case is X-linked dominant.

On exam, the boy is lethargic but responsive. He appears to be grasping at his ears and swaying from side-to-side when attempting to ambulate. He vomited once in the emergency room. Which of the following arterial blood gas readings is most likely to be found in this patient?

[A] : pH 7.29, PCO2 47 mmHg, and HCO3- 22 mEq/L
[B] : pH 7.35, PCO2 29 mmHg, and HCO3- 15 mEq/L
[C] : pH 7.36, PCO2 22 mmHg, and HCO3- 16 mEq/L
[D] : pH 7.47, PCO2 41 mmHg, and HCO3- 29 mEq/L
<|end|><|assistant|> The boy has ingested multiple medications, including aspirin, which is a known cause of salicylate toxicity. Salicylate toxicity can lead to a mixed acid-base disturbance. Initially, it causes respiratory alkalosis due to direct stimulation of the respiratory center, leading to hyperventilation and a decrease in PCO2. As the condition progresses, metabolic acidosis can develop due to the accumulation of organic acids.

Given the boy's symptoms of lethargy, vomiting, and the fact that he is found next to multiple open pill bottles, it is likely that he has ingested a significant amount of salicylates. The respiratory alkalosis would be characterized by a low PCO2 due to hyperventilation. The metabolic acidosis would be characterized by a low HCO3- due to the accumulation of organic acids.

The most likely arterial blood gas (ABG) reading in this case would show a primary respiratory alkalosis with a compensatory metabolic acidosis. This would be reflected in a low PCO2 and a low HCO3-. The pH would be on the alkalotic side due to the primary respiratory alkalosis but may be near normal or slightly decreased due to the compensatory metabolic acidosis.

Option A (pH 7.29, PCO2 47 mmHg, and HCO3- 22 mEq/L) suggests a primary metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation, which is not consistent with the expected presentation of salicylate toxicity.

Option B (pH 7.35, PCO2 29 mmHg, and HCO3- 15 mEq/L) suggests a primary respiratory alkalosis with a significant compensatory metabolic acidosis, which is consistent with the expected presentation of salicylate toxicity.

Option C (pH 7.36, PCO2 22 mmHg, and HCO3- 16 mEq/L) suggests a primary respiratory alkalosis with a significant compensatory metabolic acidosis, but the pH is not as low as would be expected in a significant toxicity case.

Option D (pH 7.47, PCO2 41 mmHg, and HCO3- 29 mEq/L) suggests a primary metabolic alkalosis with no respiratory compensation, which is not consistent with the expected presentation of salicylate toxicity.

The most likely ABG reading in this case of salicylate toxicity would be a primary respiratory alkalosis with a compensatory metabolic acidosis, which is best represented by option [B].

So, the answer is [B]. pH 7.35, PCO2 29 mmHg, and HCO3- 15 mEq/L.<|end|>

The pain is described as burning in quality and is concentrated around his epigastric region following food ingestion. It does not radiate anywhere and is alleviated when he takes antacids. A physical examination demonstrates a healthy male with unremarkable findings. He is subsequently prescribed a new medication for control of his symptoms. What is the most likely mechanism of action of this new medication?

[A] : Irreversible inactivation of cyclooxygenase enzyme
[B] : Irreversible inhibition of H+/K+-ATPase at parietal cells
[C] : Reversible inhibition of H+/K+-ATPase at parietal cells
[D] : Reversible inhibition of histamine H2 receptors
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient is experiencing symptoms of GERD, which is a condition where stomach acid frequently flows back into the tube connecting the mouth and stomach (esophagus). This backwash (acid reflux) can irritate the lining of the esophagus.

Cimetidine is a histamine H2 receptor antagonist that works by blocking H2 receptors on the parietal cells in the stomach, which reduces the production of stomach acid. However, the patient's symptoms have worsened, indicating that cimetidine is no longer effective for him.

The new medication prescribed to the patient is likely to be a proton pump inhibitor (PPI), which is a class of drugs that irreversibly inhibit the H+/K+-ATPase enzyme system (the proton pump) of the gastric parietal cells. This enzyme is responsible for the secretion of gastric acid into the stomach. By inhibiting this enzyme, PPIs reduce the production of stomach acid, providing relief from the symptoms of GER[D].

Given the options provided:

[A]. Irreversible inactivation of cyclooxygenase enzyme - This is the mechanism of action of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), not typically used for GER[D].
[B]. Irreversible inhibition of H+/K+-ATPase at parietal cells - This is the mechanism of action of PPIs, which are commonly used to treat GER[D].
[C]. Reversible inhibition of H+/K+-ATPase at parietal cells - This is the mechanism of action of H2 receptor antagonists like cimetidine, which the patient was previously taking.
[D]. Reversible inhibition of histamine H2 receptors - This is also the mechanism of action of H2 receptor antagonists, but since the patient's symptoms have worsened on cimetidine, it is less likely that the new medication is also an H2 receptor antagonist.

The most likely new medication is a PPI, which has the mechanism of action described in option [B].

So, the answer is [B]. Irreversible inhibition of H+/K+-ATPase at parietal cells.<|end|>

2025-12-12 02:39:22,963 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for evaluation of progressively worsening swelling around the eyes. Physical examination shows moderate periorbital edema and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities bilaterally. A kidney biopsy specimen shows effacement of the podocytes on electron microscopy. Which of the following is most likely to be found on urinalysis?

[A] : Hyaline casts and immunoglobulins
[B] : Fatty casts and albumin
[C] : White blood cell casts and eosinophils
[D] : Granular casts and tubular epithelial cells
<|end|><|assistant|> The clinical presentation of the 7-year-old boy with periorbital edema and pitting edema of the lower extremities, along with a history of a recent upper respiratory infection, is suggestive of nephrotic syndrome. Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by heavy proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, and edema. The effacement of podocytes on electron microscopy is a classic finding in nephrotic syndrome.

In nephrotic syndrome, the urine typically contains a large amount of protein, predominantly albumin, due to increased permeability of the glomerular basement membrane. This proteinuria can lead to the presence of fatty casts, which are formed from lipids that are excreted in the urine when the liver tries to compensate for the loss of albumin by increasing lipid synthesis.

The other options are less likely in this scenario:
[A]. Hyaline casts and immunoglobulins are more indicative of a post-infectious glomerulonephritis, which typically presents with hematuria and red blood cell casts, not the heavy proteinuria seen in nephrotic syndrome.
[C]. White blood cell casts and eosinophils are characteristic of acute interstitial nephritis or allergic interstitial nephritis, which is not consistent with the presentation of nephrotic syndrome.
[D]. Granular casts and tubular epithelial cells are seen in acute tubular necrosis or other forms of acute kidney injury, which also do not match the clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome.

So, the answer is [B]. Fatty casts and albumin.<|end|>
2025-12-12 02:39:22,964 - INFO - question 905/1273 answer:B correct_answer:B True
2025-12-12 02:39:38,946 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> Background: There is a lack of consensus about whether the initial imaging method for patients with suspected nephrolithiasis should be computed tomography (CT) or ultrasonography.
Methods: In this multicenter, pragmatic, comparative effectiveness trial, we randomly assigned patients 18 to 76 years of age who presented to the emergency department with suspected nephrolithiasis to undergo initial diagnostic ultrasonography performed by an emergency physician (point-of-care ultrasonography), ultrasonography performed by a radiologist (radiology ultrasonography), or abdominal non-contrast CT. Subsequent management, including additional imaging, was at the discretion of the physician. We compared the three groups with respect to the 30-day incidence of high-risk diagnoses with complications that could be related to missed or delayed diagnosis and the 6-month cumulative radiation exposure. Secondary outcomes were serious adverse events, related serious adverse events (deemed attributable to study participation), pain (assessed on an 11-point visual-analog scale, with higher scores indicating more severe pain), return emergency department visits, hospitalizations, and diagnostic accuracy.
Results: A total of 2759 patients underwent randomization: 908 to point-of-care ultrasonography, 893 to radiology ultrasonography, and 958 to non-contrast CT abdomen The incidence of high-risk diagnoses with complications in the first 30 days was low (0.4%) and did not vary according to imaging method. The mean 6-month cumulative radiation exposure was significantly lower in the ultrasonography groups than in the CT group (p < 0.001). Serious adverse events occurred in 12.4% of the patients assigned to point-of-care ultrasonography, 10.8% of those assigned to radiology ultrasonography, and 11.2% of those assigned to CT (p = 0.50). Related adverse events were infrequent (incidence, 0.4%) and similar across groups. By 7 days, the average pain score was 2.0 in each group (p = 0.84). Return emergency department visits, hospitalizations, and diagnostic accuracy did not differ significantly among the groups.
Conclusions: Initial ultrasonography was associated with lower cumulative radiation exposure than initial CT, without significant differences in high-risk diagnoses with complications, serious adverse events, pain scores, return emergency department visits, or hospitalizations.
If the conclusion stated above was, in fact, due to the earlier detection of nephrolithiasis in patients undergoing point of care ultrasound, what type of bias would this exemplify?

[A] : Measurement bias
[B] : Recall bias
[C] : Lead-time bias
[D] : Selection bias
<|end|><|assistant|> The conclusion suggests that initial ultrasonography was associated with lower cumulative radiation exposure than initial CT without significant differences in high-risk diagnoses with complications, serious adverse events, pain scores, return emergency department visits, or hospitalizations. If the conclusion was due to the earlier detection of nephrolithiasis in patients undergoing point-of-care ultrasound, this would be an example of lead-time bias.

Lead-time bias occurs when early detection of a disease (due to more sensitive screening methods) is mistaken for an increase in survival time, when in fact the earlier detection has not changed the natural history of the disease. In this case, if point-of-care ultrasonography detects nephrolithiasis earlier than CT, it might appear as though ultrasonography is more effective, when in reality, it may just be identifying the condition sooner.

So, the answer is [C]. Lead-time bias.<|end|>

[D] : QTc prolongation
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's symptoms suggest that she may be suffering from depression, and she is also trying to quit smoking. A drug that can treat both depression and aid in smoking cessation is bupropion, which is an atypical antidepressant and a smoking cessation aid.

Bupropion works by inhibiting the reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine, which can help alleviate depressive symptoms. It is also used to help people stop smoking by reducing the desire to smoke and withdrawal symptoms.

One of the known side effects of bupropion is that it can cause seizures, especially in individuals with a history of eating disorders, alcoholism, or withdrawal from alcohol or benzodiazepines. However, this is not one of the options provided.

Looking at the options given:

[A]. Hypotension - Bupropion is not typically associated with causing hypotension.
[B]. Urinary retention - Bupropion does not commonly cause urinary retention.
[C]. Tachycardia - Bupropion can cause an increase in heart rate, or tachycardia, as a side effect.
[D]. QTc prolongation - Bupropion is not known to cause QTc prolongation.

Given these considerations, the side effect that the patient should be counseled about is tachycardia.

So, the answer is [C]. Tachycardia.<|end|>

2025-12-12 02:42:56,011 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 30-year-old female presents to her primary care provider complaining of 4 days of fever, malaise, dyspnea, and productive cough and has recently developed pleuritic chest pain. Her past medical history is notable for asthma and takes albuterol as needed. She does not smoke but drinks alcohol socially. Her family history is notable for cystic fibrosis in her paternal uncle and interstitial lung disease in her paternal grandfather. Her temperature is 101°F (38.3°C), blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 21/min. Rales are noted in the right lower lung, and a chest radiograph demonstrates focal consolidation in the right lower lung lobe. After initiating the appropriate treatment, she agrees to take part in a study assessing the immune response to lung infections. A protein is identified in her serum that is thought to be elevated in response to her condition. An amino acid sequence at the carboxy terminus of the protein is isolated and a fluorescent marker is added to the sequence. This labeled sequence is subsequently added to a gel containing a protein isolated from the cell surface of the patient’s own neutrophils and macrophages and subsequently labeled with another fluorescent marker. The sequence binds strongly to this protein as evidenced by increased fluorescence in the gel. What process does this sequence typically undergo in immunocompetent individuals?

[A] : Random assortment
[B] : Random nucleotide addition
[C] : VDJ recombination
[D] : Isotype switching
<|end|><|assistant|> The scenario described involves a protein that is elevated in response to a lung infection, which suggests an immune response. The protein in question is likely an antibody, given the context of the study and the use of fluorescent markers to track its binding to cell surface proteins.

In immunocompetent individuals, the process that generates the diversity of antibodies is VDJ recombination. This process occurs in B cells and involves the random recombination of variable (V), diversity (D), and joining (J) gene segments to create a unique variable region of the antibody's heavy and light chains. This recombination is a crucial part of the adaptive immune response, allowing the immune system to recognize a vast array of antigens.

The other options listed do not describe the process of generating antibody diversity:

[A]. Random assortment is not a term typically used in the context of antibody production.
[B]. Random nucleotide addition refers to the addition of nucleotides during the somatic hypermutation process, which occurs after VDJ recombination and is part of affinity maturation.
[D]. Isotype switching is a process that occurs in B cells where the constant region of the antibody is changed, allowing the same antigen-binding site to be used with different classes of antibodies (e.g., IgM, IgG, IgA).

Given the context of the question and the description of the protein's production, the correct answer is the process that generates the diversity of antibodies in immunocompetent individuals.

So, the answer is [C]. VDJ recombination.<|end|>
2025-12-12 02:42:56,012 - INFO - question 914/1273 answer:C correct_answer:D False
2025-12-12 02:43:29,596 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 27-year-old graduate student is bitten by a coral snake while he was hiking alone through the woods and dies 2 hours later from respiratory failure. His body was discovered 7 hours later by a group of campers who promptly called the police. On arrival, the police found his body to be cold and stiff. Which of the following processes is responsible for the rigidity observed?

[A] : Activation of muscle contraction by neurotoxins
[B] : Effect of low temperature on muscle proteins
[C] : Inhibition of cross-bridge cycling
[D] : Depletion of intracellular calcium
<|end|><|assistant|> The scenario describes a case of envenomation by a coral snake, which is known to have neurotoxins in its venom. These neurotoxins can cause paralysis by blocking the transmission of nerve impulses to the muscles. The specific process that leads to muscle rigidity and paralysis is the inhibition of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction. This prevents the neurotransmitter acetylcholine from binding to its receptors on the muscle cell membrane, which is necessary for muscle contraction.

The inhibition of cross-bridge cycling is a consequence of this blockade. Cross-bridge cycling is the process by which myosin heads in the muscle fibers bind to actin to form cross-bridges, then pull the actin filaments toward the center of the sarcomere, resulting in muscle contraction. When the neurotoxins in the snake venom inhibit the receptors, they prevent the initiation of this cycle, leading to muscle rigidity and eventually paralysis.

The other options can be considered as follows:
[A]. Activation of muscle contraction by neurotoxins is incorrect because the neurotoxins actually inhibit muscle contraction, not activate it.
[B]. Effect of low temperature on muscle proteins could cause stiffness, but this would not be the primary cause of the rigidity observed in this case, which is due to the snake venom.
[D]. Depletion of intracellular calcium would lead to muscle relaxation, not rigidity.

So, the answer is [C]. Inhibition of cross-bridge cycling.<|end|>

2025-12-12 02:43:56,345 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 28-year-old G1P0 woman at 12 weeks estimated gestational age presents with malaise, joint pain, fever, and chills for the past 3 days. [A] : It can lead to hydrops fetalis secondary to fetal anemia.
[B] : It can cause aplastic crisis in the neonate.
[C] : Fetal loss occurs in more than 40% of primary infections.
[D] : The neonate may be born with a typical slapped-cheek rash.
<|end|><|assistant|> Parvovirus B19 is known to cause a variety of symptoms in humans, ranging from mild to severe. In adults, it often presents with a flu-like illness, which can include fever, malaise, and joint pain. The rash associated with parvovirus B19 is indeed lace-like or reticular, which can be a distinguishing feature of the infection.

In pregnant women, parvovirus B19 infection can have serious consequences for the fetus. The virus can cross the placenta and infect the fetal red blood cells, leading to fetal anemia. Severe fetal anemia can result in hydrops fetalis, a condition where there is an abnormal accumulation of fluid in two or more fetal compartments, such as the skin, chest, abdomen, or heart. Hydrops fetalis is a serious condition that can be life-threatening for the fetus.

Regarding the other options:
[B]. Aplastic crisis in the neonate is more commonly associated with infections that affect the bone marrow, such as parvovirus B19 in the neonate, but it is not the primary concern in a pregnant woman.
[C]. Fetal loss does occur with parvovirus B19 infection, but the rate is not as high as 40% for primary infections. The rate of fetal loss can vary, but it is generally lower than this figure.
[D]. The "slapped-cheek" rash is characteristic of parvovirus B19 infection in children, not in the fetus.

Given the information provided, the correct statement regarding the effect of parvovirus B19 infection in this pregnant patient is that it can lead to hydrops fetalis secondary to fetal anemia.

So, the answer is [A].<|end|>

2025-12-12 02:44:26,385 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 52-year-old man with hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes to the emergency department 30 minutes after the sudden onset of substernal chest pain while sitting in a chair at home. He reports drinking 2 glasses of whiskey earlier that day, after a stressful day at work. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. His pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 135/88 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows normal heart sounds. An ECG obtained on arrival at the emergency department shows ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads. 15 minutes later, the patient's chest pain has resolved and a repeat ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient’s chest pain?

[A] : Coronary artery vasospasm
[B] : Coronary artery vasodilation
[C] : Atherosclerotic plaque rupture
[D] : Pericardial inflammation
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with sudden onset of substernal chest pain, which is a classic symptom of myocardial ischemia. The fact that the chest pain resolved quickly and was associated with ST-segment elevations that resolved within 15 minutes suggests a transient event rather than a persistent one.

[A]. Coronary artery vasospasm, also known as Prinzmetal's angina or variant angina, can cause transient ST-segment elevations due to a sudden constriction of the coronary artery. This can lead to chest pain that comes and goes, often at rest, and can resolve spontaneously as the spasm subsides.

[B]. Coronary artery vasodilation would not typically cause ST-segment elevations. Vasodilation would lead to increased blood flow to the myocardium, which is not consistent with the presentation of ischemic chest pain.

[C]. Atherosclerotic plaque rupture usually leads to the formation of a thrombus that can cause a persistent myocardial infarction, not a transient event. This would not explain the rapid resolution of the chest pain and the ST-segment elevations.

[D]. Pericardial inflammation, or pericarditis, can cause chest pain and ST-segment elevations. However, the pain from pericarditis is typically positional and may worsen with inspiration or when lying down. It is also less likely to resolve so quickly without treatment.

Given the transient nature of the chest pain and the ST-segment elevations that resolved quickly, the most likely underlying mechanism is coronary artery vasospasm.

So, the answer is [A]. Coronary artery vasospasm.<|end|>

2025-12-12 02:45:04,122 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a sudden loss of consciousness. He has asthma and has been hospitalized multiple times. His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is somnolent and diaphoretic. Serum studies show a glucose concentration of 22 mg/dL and a potassium concentration of 2.4 mEq/L. A dextrose infusion is administered, after which his glucose concentration normalizes and his symptoms improve. He is admitted to the hospital for further observation. Overnight, he has another episode of decreased consciousness. Serum studies taken during the episode show a glucose concentration of 19 mg/dL, an insulin concentration of 108 mIU/L (N=2.6–24.9), and a C-peptide concentration of 0.3 ng/mL (N = 0.8–3.1). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

[A] : Malingering
[B] : Primary adrenal insufficiency
[C] : Conversion disorder
[D] : Factitious disorder imposed on another
"
<|end|><|assistant|> The boy presents with a sudden loss of consciousness, which is a concerning symptom that requires medical evaluation. His history of asthma and hospitalizations, along with the mother's type 2 diabetes, may be relevant to his overall health but do not directly point to the cause of his symptoms.

The key findings in the scenario are the low glucose concentration (hypoglycemia) and the high insulin concentration with a low C-peptide concentration during the episode of decreased consciousness. Insulin is a hormone that lowers blood glucose levels, and C-peptide is a byproduct of insulin production. A high insulin level with a low C-peptide level suggests that the insulin is not being produced by the patient's own pancreas but is being administered externally.

This is indicative of factitious disorder imposed on another (previously known as Munchausen syndrome by proxy), where a caregiver administers harmful substances to a dependent individual, often a child, to cause symptoms. In this case, the mother could be administering insulin to the child to cause hypoglycemia, which can lead to loss of consciousness.

Malingering (option A) involves the intentional production of false or grossly exaggerated physical or psychological symptoms, motivated by external incentives such as avoiding work or obtaining financial compensation. There is no indication of external incentives in this scenario.

Primary adrenal insufficiency (option B) can cause hypoglycemia due to cortisol deficiency, but it would not explain the high insulin and low C-peptide levels during the episode.

Conversion disorder (option C) involves neurological symptoms that are inconsistent with neurological disease and are thought to arise in response to psychological stress. However, the laboratory findings of high insulin and low C-peptide levels are not consistent with conversion disorder.

Given the laboratory findings and the clinical context, the most likely diagnosis is factitious disorder imposed on another, where the mother is administering insulin to the child to cause hypoglycemia.

So, the answer is [D]. Factitious disorder imposed on another.<|end|>

<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with symptoms of urinary retention, as evidenced by difficulty urinating, incomplete voiding, and a distended bladder palpable in the suprapubic region. [B] : Straight leg raise
[C] : Internal rotation of the extended hip
[D] : Radiography
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's symptoms of lower back pain radiating down the leg with an "electrical" sensation are suggestive of sciatica, which is often caused by irritation or compression of the sciatic nerve. This can occur due to a herniated disc or other spinal pathology.

[C]. Internal rotation of the extended hip - This maneuver is also used to assess for hip pathology and is not specific for diagnosing sciatica.

[D]. Radiography - While plain radiographs (X-rays) can be useful in identifying fractures or degenerative changes in the spine, they are not as sensitive as other imaging modalities, such as MRI, for diagnosing herniated discs or other soft tissue causes of sciatica.

Differential count:
Neutrophile 70%
Lymphocytes 25%
Monocytes 5%
ESR 10 mm/hr
What is the most likely diagnosis?

[A] : Plummer-Vinson syndrome
[B] : Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma
[C] : Zenker’s diverticulum
[D] : Achalasia
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with fatigue, mild neck pain, difficulty swallowing (dysphagia), and unintentional weight loss. These symptoms, along with the finding of an upper esophageal web on the barium esophagram, are suggestive of a condition that affects the esophagus.

This syndrome is more common in middle-aged women and can lead to an increased risk of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

Achalasia is a motility disorder of the esophagus that leads to difficulty swallowing both solids and liquids, regurgitation of food, and sometimes weight loss. It does not typically present with anemia or esophageal webs.

Given the combination of symptoms, physical exam findings, and the presence of an esophageal web, the most likely diagnosis is Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

2025-12-12 02:46:23,603 - INFO - question 921/1273 answer:A correct_answer:A True
2025-12-12 02:47:03,104 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 65-year-old female patient comes to the physician’s office for her annual check-up. The patient’s only complaint is that she feels her vision has been getting more blurry over the past year. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes diagnosed 20 years ago and osteoarthritis. Her medications include metformin, glimepiride, and ibuprofen as needed for pain. Fundoscopic examination of this patient reveals narrowing of retinal arteries and microaneurysms. This patient’s symptoms are likely caused by tissue specific differences in expression of which of the following enzymes?

[A] : Sorbitol dehydrogenase
[B] : Galactocerebrosidase
[C] : Arylsulfatase A
[D] : Sphingomyelinase
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient has a history of diabetes and is experiencing blurry vision. The fundoscopic examination reveals narrowing of retinal arteries and microaneurysms, which are signs consistent with diabetic retinopathy. Diabetic retinopathy is a complication of diabetes caused by damage to the blood vessels of the light-sensitive tissue at the back of the eye (retina).

One of the key factors in the development of diabetic complications, including diabetic retinopathy, is the accumulation of sorbitol within cells. This occurs due to the polyol pathway, where glucose is reduced to sorbitol by the enzyme aldose reductase. In individuals with diabetes, high blood glucose levels lead to an increased flux through this pathway. The sorbitol produced can accumulate within cells, leading to osmotic stress and damage.

The enzyme sorbitol dehydrogenase is responsible for converting sorbitol to fructose, which can then be further metabolized. In individuals with diabetes, the activity of sorbitol dehydrogenase is often insufficient to prevent the accumulation of sorbitol, leading to the complications associated with diabetes, such as diabetic retinopathy.

The other enzymes listed have different roles and are associated with other conditions:

[B]. Galactocerebrosidase is an enzyme that, when deficient, leads to Krabbe disease, a rare inherited disorder affecting the nervous system.

[C]. Arylsulfatase A is an enzyme whose deficiency leads to metachromatic leukodystrophy, a condition that affects the white matter of the brain and spinal cord.

[D]. Sphingomyelinase is an enzyme whose deficiency causes Niemann-Pick disease, a group of inherited lysosomal storage disorders.

Given the patient's history of diabetes and the symptoms described, the tissue-specific differences in enzyme expression that are likely causing her symptoms are related to the polyol pathway and the enzyme sorbitol dehydrogenase.

So, the answer is [A]. Sorbitol dehydrogenase.<|end|>

If correct, which of these functional maneuvers would you expect to be deficient on physical exam?

[A] : Initiation of adduction
[B] : External rotation
[C] : Initiation of abduction
[D] : Internal rotation
<|end|><|assistant|> The supraspinatus muscle is one of the four rotator cuff muscles in the shoulder. Its primary function is to initiate the first 15-30 degrees of shoulder abduction. After this initial phase, the deltoid muscle takes over to complete the abduction of the arm. When the supraspinatus is torn, the patient typically has difficulty with this initial phase of abduction.

[A]. Initiation of adduction - This is not a function of the supraspinatus; adduction is primarily performed by muscles such as the latissimus dorsi and pectoralis major.
[B]. External rotation - This is mainly performed by the infraspinatus and teres minor muscles.
[D]. Internal rotation - This is performed by the subscapularis muscle, which is another rotator cuff muscle.

Given that the supraspinatus is responsible for the initiation of abduction, a deficiency in this maneuver would be expected if the supraspinatus were torn.

[C] : Joint effusion and pannus on ultrasound
[D] : Fluid-filled pouch on ultrasound
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient presents with symptoms that are consistent with osteoarthritis (OA), which is a common degenerative joint disease, especially in middle-aged and older adults. The symptoms include joint pain that worsens with activity, stiffness that typically lasts less than 30 minutes upon waking, and crepitus with movement of the affected joint. The patient's history of hypercholesterolemia and hypertension, along with her BMI of 31.8 kg/m^2, which classifies her as obese, are risk factors for O[A].

On imaging, the most common findings in OA are osteophytes (bone spurs) and joint-space narrowing due to cartilage loss. These findings are best visualized on an x-ray of the affected joint.

Option B, diffuse lytic-sclerotic bone lesions on x-ray, would be more suggestive of a metabolic bone disease or malignancy. Option C, joint effusion and pannus on ultrasound, is more indicative of an inflammatory arthritis such as rheumatoid arthritis. Option D, a fluid-filled pouch on ultrasound, could suggest a Baker's cyst, which is often associated with OA but is not a primary finding on imaging.

Given the clinical presentation and the typical findings in OA, the most likely imaging finding would be osteophytes with joint-space narrowing on x-ray.

2025-12-12 02:48:43,409 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 6-month-old boy presents to a pediatrician for the evaluation of recurrent bacterial infections. The pediatrician suspects an immunodeficiency disorder and decides to order several tests. Study of the boy’s neutrophils reveals that they contain large cytoplasmic vacuoles. Genetic studies show a mutation in the LYST gene. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

[A] : Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS)
[B] : Common variable immunodeficiency
[C] : Chediak-Higashi syndrome
[D] : Leukocyte adhesion deficiency–1
<|end|><|assistant|> The clinical presentation of recurrent bacterial infections, light-colored skin, and silver-colored hair, along with the finding of large cytoplasmic vacuoles in neutrophils and a mutation in the LYST gene, is characteristic of Chediak-Higashi syndrome. This is a rare, autosomal recessive disorder that affects multiple systems, including the immune system. The LYST gene mutation leads to abnormal lysosomal trafficking, which is responsible for the formation of the large cytoplasmic vacuoles in the neutrophils.

Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) is caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and is not associated with the LYST gene mutation or the described physical findings.

Common variable immunodeficiency is a disorder characterized by low levels of serum immunoglobulins and an increased susceptibility to infections, but it does not typically present with the physical findings described, nor is it associated with the LYST gene mutation.

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency–1 is a disorder that affects the ability of leukocytes to migrate to sites of infection, leading to recurrent bacterial infections. However, it does not cause the characteristic physical findings or the LYST gene mutation.

So, the answer is [C]. Chediak-Higashi syndrome.<|end|>

Arthrocentesis yields cloudy fluid with a leukocyte count of 18,500/mm3 (80% segmented neutrophils). Polarized light microscopy of the synovial fluid is shown. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the most appropriate long-term pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition?

[A] : Increased conversion of uric acid to allantoin
[B] : Inhibition of phospholipase A
[C] : Inhibition of xanthine oxidase
[D] : Increased renal excretion of urate
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient's symptoms and history suggest that he is experiencing an acute gout attack, which is characterized by sudden onset of severe pain, swelling, and redness in a joint, often the big toe. Gout is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in the joints due to hyperuricemia, which is an elevated level of uric acid in the blood.

The patient's serum uric acid level is 12 mg/dL, which is above the normal range (typically 3.5 to 7.2 mg/dL for men). His arthrocentesis shows cloudy fluid with a high leukocyte count and a predominance of segmented neutrophils, which is consistent with an inflammatory process such as gout. Polarized light microscopy of the synovial fluid would likely show negatively birefringent needle-shaped urate crystals, confirming the diagnosis of gout.

For long-term management of gout, the goal is to reduce serum uric acid levels to prevent future attacks and to dissolve existing urate crystals. The options provided are mechanisms of action for different drugs used in the management of gout:

[A]. Increased conversion of uric acid to allantoin - This is the mechanism of action of uricosuric agents, which increase the renal excretion of uric acid.

[B]. Inhibition of phospholipase A - This is not a mechanism associated with the treatment of gout.

[C]. Inhibition of xanthine oxidase - This is the mechanism of action of allopurinol and febuxostat, which are xanthine oxidase inhibitors. These drugs reduce the production of uric acid and are used for long-term management of gout.

[D]. Increased renal excretion of urate - This is the mechanism of action of uricosuric agents, which are used to increase the excretion of uric acid in the urine.

The most appropriate long-term pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition would be a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, as it would reduce the production of uric acid and prevent future gout attacks.

So, the answer is [C]. Inhibition of xanthine oxidase.<|end|>

[A] : Administer dopamine
[B] : Administer glucagon
[C] : Administer dexamethasone
[D] : Administer norepinephrine

The first-line treatment for anaphylaxis is epinephrine, which has already been administered to this patient. However, the patient remains hypotensive despite aggressive fluid resuscitation and intramuscular epinephrine. In such cases, additional vasopressors may be required to maintain blood pressure and ensure adequate organ perfusion.

Dopamine (option A) is a vasopressor that can be used to treat hypotension, but it is not the first choice in anaphylaxis because it does not address the underlying allergic reaction and can cause tachycardia, which may exacerbate angioedema.

Glucagon (option B) is used to treat beta-blocker overdose or severe hypoglycemia, not anaphylaxis.

Norepinephrine (option D) is a potent vasopressor and is the next best step in the management of this patient. It can help to increase blood pressure by vasoconstriction and is often used when hypotension persists despite epinephrine and fluid resuscitation.

[A] : Leuprolide
[B] : Finasteride
[C] : Flutamide
[D] : Anastrozole
<|end|><|assistant|> The patient is being treated with a drug that reduces the action of testosterone by blocking the androgen receptor. This is a description of an anti-androgen. The drug X is also noted to be excreted by the kidneys, which is a clue that it is likely a small molecule drug.

[A]. Leuprolide is a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist. It works by initially stimulating the release of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), but with continuous use, it downregulates the GnRH receptors in the pituitary gland, leading to decreased production of testosterone. [D]. Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor. It prevents the conversion of androgens to estrogens in postmenopausal women and is used in the treatment of breast cancer. It is not an androgen receptor blocker.

So, the answer is [C]. Flutamide.<|end|>

2025-12-12 02:50:55,471 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A 74-year-old man was admitted to the hospital after falling down several stairs. He is a known alcoholic. He was started on IV fluids and received a head CT, which was negative. It was decided that he would be watched for one day before being discharged, after a negative work-up. Suddenly, he is unable to move his arms and legs in addition to experiencing difficulty chewing, swallowing, moving his face, and speaking. Which of the following electrolyte imbalances was most likely corrected too aggressively?

[A] : Hyponatremia
[B] : Hypernatremia
[C] : Hypokalemia
[D] : Hypochloremia
<|end|><|assistant|> The symptoms described in the scenario—impaired movement of arms and legs, difficulty chewing, swallowing, moving the face, and speaking—are indicative of a condition known as central pontine myelinolysis (CPM), also known as osmotic demyelination syndrome. This condition is often associated with the rapid correction of hyponatremia (low sodium levels in the blood).

CPM occurs when there is a too-rapid increase in serum sodium concentration, which can cause damage to the myelin sheath of nerve cells in the pons and other areas of the brain. This damage disrupts the normal function of the nerves, leading to the symptoms described.

Hyponatremia can be caused by a variety of factors, including excessive water intake, certain medications, and syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH). In the case of an alcoholic, chronic alcohol consumption can also contribute to electrolyte imbalances.

The other electrolyte imbalances listed—hypernatremia (high sodium levels), hypokalemia (low potassium levels), and hypochloremia (low chloride levels)—can also cause neurological symptoms, but the acute onset of the symptoms described is most consistent with the overly aggressive correction of hyponatremia leading to CPM.

So, the answer is [A]. Hyponatremia.<|end|>

2025-12-12 02:51:31,591 - INFO - outputs text: <|user|> A previously healthy 67-year-old man comes to the physician for routine health maintenance evaluation.
